1.content:
[DUNGEON EARTH FIELD MANUAL]
SECTION 2.2 ‚Äî Floor Classifications and Dimensional Zones
‚õìÔ∏è Nexus Floors
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not dungeons. They‚Äôre intersections. And every Earth‚Äôs got at least one.‚Äù

Function: Connects surface-level Earths (including alternate timelines) to the deeper dungeon layers.

Common Locations: Suburbs, basements, abandoned malls, parking structures, forgotten infrastructure

Key Features:

Used for interdimensional and intercontinental travel. E.g., NYC to Tokyo in under an hour via dungeon-warp.

Allows for territorial expansion. (e.g., NYC gains entirely new boroughs; Puerto Rico expands to the size of France.)

Typically habitable and not hostile‚Äîsometimes even treated as novelty cities or frontier tourist towns.

Known Complications: Nexus corridors are often unstable during high-use or under heavy magical stress. Avoid rush hour.

üß± Standard Dungeons
‚ÄúYour classic goblin-stabbing, loot-grabbing, fireball-casting caves.‚Äù

Function: Basic dungeon encounters, training grounds, and loot sites

Size: Small to Medium (~1‚Äì5 floors)

Threat Level: Low to Moderate

Features:

Linear paths, monster nests, trap rooms, treasure chests

Great for solo adventurers or rookie teams

Analogy: D&D starter dungeon or Skyrim bandit cave

üè∞ Mega Dungeons
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the monsters that‚Äôll kill you. It‚Äôs the logistics.‚Äù

Function: Large-scale, multi-floor dungeons with built-in infrastructure

Size: ~20‚Äì200 floors

Key Features:

Includes rest stops, trading hubs, repair zones, neutral safe zones

Contains faction outposts, sometimes entire guild strongholds

Strategic Role: Staging grounds for deeper expeditions; serve as quasi-mini cities

Analogy: Think Dark Souls meets Deep Rock Galactic

üåÑ Region-Class Dungeons
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just a dungeon. It‚Äôs a whole damn country underground.‚Äù

Function: Large-scale dungeon regions with permanent settlements

Size: Province-scale (~Skyrim map size)

Features:

Multiple towns, cities, and dungeon-native civilizations

Often includes guild headquarters, black markets, and full-on governments

Easy access to both deeper dungeon layers and resource veins

Examples:

New Boston ‚Äì A US-led colonial hub helping adventurers navigate the NAZ zone

Usage: Ideal for establishing long-term bases, trade operations, and political influence

üåç Earth-Class Dungeons
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not in a dungeon. You‚Äôre on a planet that thinks it‚Äôs a dungeon.‚Äù

Function: Fully habitable planetary-level floors

Size: Earth-scale

Features:

Stable climates, multiple biomes, cities, continents

Often colonized by surface nations, corporations, or dungeon-native species

Highly desirable for settlement, farming, manufacturing, and power projection

Quirks: Some resemble Earth 1:1; others are warped (e.g., green South Pole, no North Pole)

‚òÄÔ∏è Solar System-Class Dungeons
‚ÄúMultiple planets. Multiple moons. No gods, only contracts.‚Äù

Function: Dungeon layers containing entire solar systems

Size: Multi-planetary scale

Features:

Celestial bodies that follow their own gravitational logic

Factions compete for control of planetary systems

Ideal for heavy industry, magical research, and deep-civilization development

Challenges:

Travel requires advanced tech or portal mastery

Local anomalies (e.g., undead suns, sentient planets) are not uncommon

üåå Galaxy-Class Dungeons
‚ÄúWhen your dungeon has multiple galaxies inside it, you stop calling it a ‚Äòdungeon‚Äô and start calling it ‚Äòhome.‚Äô‚Äù

Function: Host multiple solar systems and stellar empires

Features:

Fully functioning galactic civilizations exist inside some

Viable to build and maintain intergalactic internet within the layer

Requires FTL or equivalent magical transport

Value: Goldmine of ancient tech, hidden empires, and exploitable resources

Notable Factions:

The Lysarin Empire has claimed entire sectors of galaxy-class dungeons

üåÄ Universe-Class Dungeons
‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt call it infinite. They call it recursive.‚Äù

Function: Self-contained, infinite (or near-infinite) universes sealed within the dungeon structure

Rarity: Extremely rare ‚Äì fewer than 50 known across all Nexus-linked Earths

Features:

Reality operates by its own physical, magical, or metaphysical rules

Includes multiversal recursion, overlapping timelines, and ‚Äúdream worlds‚Äù

Often contains sentient floor laws‚Äîrealities that actively resist being colonized

Use Cases:

Ultimate resource extraction (if survivable)

Time-space experiments

Dimensional refugee relocation

Networking: You can establish an internet, but it‚Äôs your own, isolated internet. Hope you like dungeon memes.

2.content:
[FACTION DOSSIER] ‚Äî United Nations Coalition (UNC)
Designation: United Nations Coalition
Codename: UNC
Founded: 2052, following Incident 5780-FEZ
Primary Mandate: Extermination of Catastrophic Threat-Level Dungeon Entities
Governing Body: U.N. Security Council, Directive 9-78
Clearance Level: CLASSIFIED ‚Äî BOARD ACCESS ONLY

Founding Context
The UNC was established after the discovery of the Fae Queen on Floor 5780 EZ. This event‚Äîlater known as 5780-FEZ‚Äîrevealed a horrifying truth: the dungeon connects to alternate dimensions where entire civilizations had been wiped out by a single entity. The Fae Queen had killed not just cities, but worlds.

There was no surface-level breach. No invasion. No war. Just proof that if she ever chose to cross over, there would be no one left to stop her.

In response, the United Nations Security Council initiated Directive 9-78. Within days, the United Nations Coalition (UNC) was formed.

Operational Philosophy
‚ÄúWe don't kill the strange.
We kill the dangerous.‚Äù
‚ÄîDirector Stonewall

The UNC does not exist to suppress knowledge, control magic, or micromanage dungeon politics. Its sole purpose is survival of Earth.

They do not engage non-lethal entities.
They do not interfere in dungeon society unless provoked.
They only act against entities classified as Extinction-Capable.

If a dungeon species can live peacefully, however odd or unsettling‚Äîit is left alone.
If a dungeon entity could, even theoretically, kill a city, a country, or a planet‚Äîit is marked for elimination.

Organization Overview
Headquarters: Codename ‚ÄúIron Citadel,‚Äù buried in undisclosed dimensional space

Structure: Multinational board, tactical divisions, kill teams, field researchers

Personnel: Drawn from elite military, black-budget labs, and dungeon-versed specialists

They often work closely with regional adventurer guilds, but only under strict operational rules. Civilian adventurers are sometimes warned away from floors under Active Kill Protocol to prevent unnecessary losses.

Relationship with Other Factions
Blue Cross: Cooperative but tense. The UNC is surgical, not humanitarian. The Blue Cross often pleads for more time with intelligent or culturally rich species‚ÄîUNC only relents if the entity is proven non-hostile and not dangerous.

The Sons of Liberty: Hostile. The Sons view the UNC as corrupt globalist overreach. UNC views the Sons as unstable liabilities with a hero complex.

Independent Guilds: Mixed. Many adventurers trust UNC to handle the ‚Äúunkillable shit,‚Äù but fear getting caught in the crossfire. UNC has strict no-civilian protocols, but floors under blackout orders are risky zones.

Threat Classification System
The UNC uses a five-tier threat system:

Class 1 ‚Äî Harmless / Contained (e.g. friendly slimes, mushroom folk)

Class 2 ‚Äî Unpredictable, but manageable (e.g. psychic birds, sentient fog)

Class 3 ‚Äî Lethal to individuals / parties (e.g. flesh hounds, wall-crawlers)

Class 4 ‚Äî City-scale hazard (e.g. void sirens, war-class necro-beasts)

Class 5 ‚Äî World-ending potential (e.g. the Fae Queen, Mirror Monarch, Clockwork Saint)

Only Class 4 and 5 qualify for extermination missions. UNC doctrine forbids waste of resources on ‚Äúnon-expansionist anomalies.‚Äù

Redacted Case Study: Operation ASH MIRROR
Target: ‚ÄúThe Mirror Monarch‚Äù (Entity-7742)

Classification: Class 5 ‚Äî Multiversal Cognitive Hazard

Status: Neutralized via recursive dimension implosion

Collateral: 0 civilian casualties, 1 team KIA, 1 timeline lost

Note: ‚ÄúEntity mimicked the appearance of a human child. Hesitation costs lives.‚Äù

Final Notes
The UNC isn‚Äôt a scalpel. It‚Äôs a failsafe. When something lives in the dungeon that shouldn‚Äôt be allowed anywhere near Earth, they are the last line of defense.

They don‚Äôt care what it looks like.
They don‚Äôt care what it says.
They only care if it can kill you‚Äîand everything you love.

3.content:
[FACTION DOSSIER] ‚Äî Sons of Liberty
Designation: Sons of Liberty
Founded: 2012, During the First U.S. Incursion Crisis
Classification: Paramilitary Adventurer Guild
Affiliation: United States (Unofficial / Sanctioned)
Operational Zones: Primarily NAZ; frequent incursions into foreign-controlled dungeon zones
Nickname(s): "The Seventh Branch," ‚ÄúDungeoneer Marines,‚Äù ‚ÄúStars & Stripes Squadron‚Äù

Origin
The Sons of Liberty were born from desperation.

In 2012, during the global incursion wave, dungeon entities surged into major metropolitan areas across the world. The U.S. military, facing chaos and lacking intel on the dungeon‚Äôs physics, held back deployment. The government stalled. The enemy did not.

So a group of rogue veterans, special forces, and ex-military personnel ignored orders. They marched into the North American dungeon entrance, armed with whatever they could carry‚Äîand they kept going.

By the end of that year, they'd reached Floor 1,000,000 NAZ.
And there, against impossible odds, they killed the Dungeon Keeper of the North American Zone.

The effect was instant: the dungeon's grip over North America shattered, and incursions dropped by 97%.

The U.S. government debated prosecuting them as domestic insurgents‚Äîuntil public opinion made it clear:

They weren‚Äôt criminals. They were heroes.

The Sons of Liberty were allowed to continue.

Modern Status
Today, the Sons of Liberty are a guild in name only. Functionally, they operate as the unofficial seventh branch of the U.S. Armed Forces.

Military Might: They possess their own tanks, air support, naval vessels, black sites, and combat-adapted dungeon tech.

Manufacturing Capacity: With government-approved contracts and access to dungeon-forged materials, they independently produce weapons, armor, and vehicles.

Government Status: Technically independent. Practically sanctioned. The federal government lets them operate due to necessity‚Äîbureaucracy slows down traditional forces, while the Sons move fast and hit hard.

They‚Äôre allowed to do what regular soldiers can‚Äôt.

Duties and Operations
Primary Role: Defend the North American Zone and suppress dungeon-level threats within U.S. interest areas.

Secondary Roles:

Law Enforcement: Many Sons act as self-appointed police within dungeon communities, particularly in lawless zones.

Expedition Clearance: Known to forcibly eject untrained adventurers or unauthorized civilians.

Territorial Defense: Enforce "American dungeon law" in any floor they secure‚Äîregardless of whose zone it technically falls under.

Recruitment
Membership is exclusive. To join, an individual must:

Be a U.S. military veteran or former armed forces member.

Swear allegiance to the United States Constitution.

Pass a trial-by-dungeon known as the Liberty Gauntlet (involving live dungeon deployment).

Patriotism and experience are required. Paperwork is not.

Cultural Profile
‚ÄúFreedom is a loaded gun and a license to use it.‚Äù
‚ÄîLt. Graves, Floor Marshal, Floor 312

Sons of Liberty view the dungeon as sovereign U.S. territory by right of conquest. They operate with a soldier‚Äôs mentality: mission-focused, survival-pragmatic, justice by the trigger.

They see bureaucracy as a weakness.
They see diplomacy as a delay.
They see the dungeon as hostile territory, 24/7.

Many carry with them a moral code‚Äîbut it‚Äôs often enforced with blunt force. They‚Äôre not subtle. They‚Äôre not always right. But they are always armed.

Controversies
Overreach in Foreign Zones: Sons have been documented enforcing American law inside British-, French-, and UN-controlled dungeon floors, resulting in diplomatic incidents.

Civilian Ejections: Reports exist of Sons forcibly removing licensed adventurers for "lack of discipline" or "no military background."

Extrajudicial Killings: In lawless zones, some units act as judge, jury, and executioner‚Äîclaiming the dungeon "has no due process."

Critics accuse them of hyper-militarism, imperialism, and acting as "a hammer that sees every monster, and every mage, as a nail."

The Sons don‚Äôt deny this.

‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt like it, you‚Äôre welcome to stop the next dungeon apocalypse yourself.‚Äù
‚ÄîCol. Rainer, during a U.N. hearing

Relationship with Other Factions
UNC: Tense cooperation. Mutual respect. Occasional clashes over jurisdiction.

Blue Cross: Philosophical opposites. The Sons protect civilians. The Cross helps monsters. This does not sit well.

Independent Guilds: Mixed. Some admire them. Some avoid them. Some call them ‚Äúdungeon cops with tank support.‚Äù

4.content:
[FACTION DOSSIER] ‚Äî The Iron Crown
Designation: The Iron Crown
Origin: Alternate Universe ‚ÄúEarth-2‚Äù
Founded: 2012 (Earth-2 calendar), following Dungeon Emergence
Affiliation: The British Empire of Earth-2
Operational Status: Active, Expansionist, Royal Decree Level
Known Territory: Over 50 confirmed colonized dungeon floors (and growing)
Symbol: A crowned lion gripping a sword and scepter, surrounded by black iron thorns

Origin: Earth-2 ‚Äî A World Without America
The Iron Crown hails not from our world, but from a parallel Earth accessible through deep dungeon traversal.

Designated ‚ÄúEarth-2‚Äù, this alternate surface is geographically identical to our Earth, but historically divergent.
The split? World War II.

In Earth-2:

The United States collapsed during the Great Depression, consumed by a Communist revolution.

The British Empire, surrounded on all sides by ideological enemies, refused to die. It doubled down on imperial control, executing revolutionary leaders (including Gandhi), crushing independence movements, and asserting absolute authority.

Over the next several decades, the British:

Conquered Korea post-war, toppling the North after bolstering the South.

Integrated Hong Kong permanently, even placing nuclear deterrents to block Chinese expansion.

Turned Canada into a fortified northern shield, deterring American refugees.

Struck down the Soviet Union, China, and the United Socialist States of America in one final imperial strike in the late 20th century.

By 2000, the British Empire controlled most of the globe.
By 2012, they were building a moon base.

And then came the Dungeon.

Formation of the Iron Crown
When dungeon rifts appeared on Earth-2, the British response was swift, ruthless, and strategic.

The King‚Äôs High Council formed the Iron Crown, a militarized expeditionary force tasked with:

Defending Earth-2 from dungeon threats

Charting and conquering dungeon floors

Preparing dungeon zones for colonization and integration into the Empire

Unlike most Earth factions, the Iron Crown didn't just explore.
They conquered.

Their motto:

‚ÄúWhat the Crown sees, the Crown holds.‚Äù

Current Operations
Governance: The Iron Crown operates directly under royal authority, answering only to the reigning King. It possesses full military autonomy.

Colonial Expansion: Over 50 dungeon floors have been brought under the Crown‚Äôs rule. Native populations are offered:

British citizenship

Infrastructure, trade, education, and military protection

Or the sword

Surface-Dungeon Integration: Floors under the Crown are treated like colonial territories.

Think 1800s India‚Äîbut underground, with magic, and filled with weird shit.

Multispecies Citizenship: Unlike older empires, the Iron Crown does not limit citizenship by species or race‚Äîonly by loyalty to the Crown. Beastkin, monsters, and dungeonfolk alike may swear allegiance and join.

Doctrine & Culture
Imperial Realism: Diplomacy is an option. Subjugation is faster.

Hardline Anti-Communism: Even alternate timeline communism is considered a spiritual blight.

Total Infrastructure Dominance: The Iron Crown builds roads, ports, forts, and rail lines in dungeon floors. You will get British trains, whether you want them or not.

Strict Discipline: Uniforms, chain of command, etiquette, and tea time are strictly enforced.

Iron Crown soldiers wear stylized red coats blended with arcane body armor. Their officers wield enchanted sabers. Some battalions march to bagpipes. All are fanatically loyal.

Relationship with Other Factions
UNC: Surprisingly friendly. Both sides share a ruthless, kill-first mindset toward world-ending entities. The Crown views the UNC as efficient, though ‚Äúundisciplined.‚Äù

Sons of Liberty: Borderline hostile. Regular skirmishes occur in contested floors. Sons view the Crown as imperialist oppressors. The Crown sees the Sons as ‚Äúrebellious colonials with an overabundance of firearms and no sense of decorum.‚Äù

Blue Cross: Tolerated but distrusted. Iron Crown officers consider them na√Øve, but useful for maintaining ‚Äúcivilized behavior among the natives.‚Äù

Criticism & Controversy
Imperialism: The Iron Crown is openly imperialist. They make no apologies.

Aggressive Expansion: Often accused of forcibly annexing floors that were previously neutral or under peaceful governance.

Cultural Dominance: Native dungeon cultures are often ‚Äúcivilized‚Äù via British systems‚Äîsome appreciate it, others resist.

Floor Rebellion Suppression: There are persistent rumors of mass suppression campaigns in rebellious floors, but no footage survives.

Known Territories Under the Crown
Floor 814 ‚Äì New Coventry: A fortified colonial capital, complete with a dungeon-adapted Parliament.

Floor 896 ‚Äì Royal Iskarn: Once ruled by a lich monarchy, now home to reformed necromancers serving in the British Dungeon Corps.

Floor 901 ‚Äì Bastion of the Unseen: Contained an invisible species; now functions as an elite Iron Crown intelligence headquarters.

Final Notes
The Iron Crown views the dungeon not as a threat‚Äîbut as the next phase of the Empire.
Where others fear monsters, the Crown sees subjects.
Where others fear gods, the Crown sees targets.
And where others fear collapse, the Crown sees order.

Long may they reign.
God Save the King.

5.content:
[INTEL PROFILE] ‚Äî His Imperial Majesty, King Edward IX
Title:
His Majesty King Edward the Ninth, Sovereign of the British Empire, Defender of the Realm Above and Below, Supreme Commander of the Iron Crown, Conqueror of the Endless Dark

Alias(es):

‚ÄúThe Iron Sovereign‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Last Monarch‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Dungeon King‚Äù

‚ÄúOld World‚Äôs First New God‚Äù (used sarcastically in Blue Cross literature)

Quick Summary
Date of Birth: July 4, 1962 (Earth-2 timeline)

Crowned: 2001

Age: 63 (biologically closer to mid-40s)

Magic Status Pre-2012: None

Post-2012: Gained magical resilience and enhancements via dungeon-alchemical modification and artifact exposure.

Pre-Dungeon History
Edward IX came into power in the final decades of the Global Restoration Campaign, when the British Empire was already dominating most of Earth-2 through a mix of military conquest, economic warfare, and Cold War cleanup. His rule began with ruthless stability:

Oversaw the final dissolution of the Soviet Bloc and American Communists.

Consolidated power through colonial reclamation and brutal suppression of independence movements.

Championed "Scientific Imperialism"‚Äîa doctrine that elevated technocrats, military elites, and economists into near-aristocratic status.

Despite his militarism, he was known for being hyper-pragmatic, not delusional. His reign focused on rebuilding a world the British Empire could permanently control‚Äîright up until 2012.

The Dungeon Emergence
The arrival of the dungeon changed everything.

Across Earth-2, rifts tore open the sky. Beasts, anomalies, horrors, and impossible geometries spilled across the land. Initial British expeditions suffered catastrophic losses.

Rather than retreat, Edward issued Royal Mandate 322-B: Total Integration of Dungeon Resources.

‚ÄúIf Hell has opened its gates, then we shall pave them with stone, and plant the Union Jack atop its throne.‚Äù
‚ÄîEdward IX, 2012, Royal Crisis Address

Post-Dungeon Evolution
Since 2012, Edward has undergone dramatic changes‚Äînone of which were inherited, and all of which were earned.

Known Enhancements:
Longevity Treatments: Based on dungeon-organics and controlled time dilation chambers. Still experimental. He‚Äôs the only confirmed subject.

Magical Exposure Resistance: Gained through repeated exposure to unstable artifact zones. Now immune to at least three classes of memetic curse.

Artifact Bonded Equipment: Wields a blade known as ‚ÄúRulebreaker‚Äù, forged from floor-core fragments and quantum iron. Not magical by default, but adapted to feed off dungeon energy.

He is still, at heart, a human with no innate magic‚Äîbut he's mastered the art of colonizing the supernatural, one experiment at a time.

Personality & Doctrine
Edward IX remains defined by discipline, order, and grand-scale ambition.

Not mystical by nature. Sees magic as a tool, not a religion.

Views dungeon floors as frontiers to be civilized, not realms to be feared.

Rejects chaos, decentralization, and compromise.

Views democracy as inherently unstable. Empires last. Votes crumble.

To dungeon-native species, he's a mix of oppressor and savior. He builds hospitals‚Äîbut under his flag. He stops gods‚Äîbut replaces them with laws. And he‚Äôs one of the only human rulers to actually survive on the deeper floors.

Relationship With Magic
Edward is a magical realist. He doesn‚Äôt believe in ‚Äúfate,‚Äù or ‚Äúdestiny,‚Äù or ‚Äúancient prophecies.‚Äù He believes in results.

His personal writings describe magic as:

‚Äú...a science with unpredictable logic. Dangerous, yes. But if it can be studied, it can be controlled. And if it can be controlled, it will serve.‚Äù

Public Persona
Earth-2 Subjects: Worshipped as a living legend. They see him as the man who tamed a collapsing world, then brought light into the dark.

Dungeon Colonists: Varied. Loyalists revere him. Rebels call him "The Iron Storm."

Earth-Prime Observers: Seen as a dangerous figure. Powerful, composed, and too smart to underestimate.

Notable Incidents
Battle of Floor 711 (Hollow Windsor): Personally led the counteroffensive against a mimic-empire, using tactical nukes and time-locked infantry waves.

The Royal Accord of Floor 936: Negotiated British citizenship for an entire race of amphibious dungeonfolk in exchange for their service as naval scouts.

Operation Iron Stamp: Ordered the execution of a rogue Iron Crown governor who tried to declare his floor independent.

Key Quotes
‚ÄúMagic did not build civilization. Man did. And magic shall serve man‚Äîor it shall perish.‚Äù
‚ÄîFrom the Royal Manual on Dungeon Integration, Vol. I

‚ÄúI was born mortal. If I now stand among gods, it is because I marched here on foot.‚Äù
‚ÄîPrivate floor-side conversation, recorded by his aide

‚ÄúFreedom is a fire. Lovely to look at, but disastrous without the right fireplace.‚Äù
‚ÄîFloor 1000 Colonization Ceremony

Final Note
Edward IX is not a wizard. He is a king who refuses to lose.

He‚Äôs the first ruler to see the dungeon not as a curse, but as a new empire waiting to be taken.

He was a warlord before 2012.
He became a conqueror afterward.
And now‚Äîhe‚Äôs the only monarch with recognized dominion over parts of the multiverse.

6.content:
[ARCHIVED FACTION REPORT] ‚Äî The Lysarin Empire
Classification: Native Dungeon Faction
Origin Date: Approx. 6,000,000,000 Years Ago (Pre-Surface Civilization)
Government Type: Eternal Theomagocracy
Species Majority: High Elves
Political Alignment: Authoritarian Magical Supremacy
Threat Assessment: ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà (Extinction-Class if Hostile)
Nickname(s):

"The Crystal Throne"

"Dungeon's Old Blood"

"Elf Nazis with Airships" (Unofficial, Sons of Liberty slang)

"Those Damn Glitter Vampires" (common EZ Zone adventurer slur)

General Overview
The Lysarin Empire is the oldest known civilization within the dungeon. Their history predates all known surface timelines‚Äîa full 6 billion years of continuous empire, sustained through arcane recordkeeping, crystal-memory dynasties, and biologically immortal bureaucracy.

They are not time-locked.
They are not remnants.
They are still here. Still thriving. Still expanding.

They are the closest thing the dungeon has to an original apex predator.

Technology & Magic
The Lysarin Empire is a fully integrated astral-punk civilization:

Crystalline power grids powered by arcane ley surges

Teleportation hubs replacing roads

Semi-sapient constructs capable of flattening battalions

Golem war machines larger than aircraft carriers

Moon-scale dreadnoughts that orbit dungeon star systems

Magic-powered biotech, including psychic memory implants and soul encryption

They do not view technology and magic as separate.
They are the same to them.

They are so advanced that even the UNC struggles to understand the materials used in Lysarin "common" infrastructure.

‚ÄúWe thought their walls were decorative. Turns out they were shielding us from extradimensional madness fields. Oops.‚Äù
‚ÄîDirector Stonewall, UNC expedition report, Floor 24019

Society & Culture
Caste-based Supremacy: At the top are the High Elves. Beneath them: nobody else matters.

Demi-human Policy: All lesser races are considered disposable.

Goblins: Slaughtered on sight

Orcs: Experimented on

Humans: Watched, manipulated, occasionally seduced

Wood Elves: Tolerated solely for cosmetic similarity

Aesthetic Fanaticism: Lysarin architecture, clothing, and military design all conform to ancient beauty codes. Ugly equals unworthy.

High elves are trained from birth in state-sanctioned magic, eugenics, politics, and music. They believe beauty is divine, and that ugliness is not just a crime‚Äîit‚Äôs a curse.

View on Humanity
‚ÄúCrude. Loud. Sentimental. But strangely adaptable. They remind us of mold that can pick locks.‚Äù
‚ÄîHigh Arcanist Vae‚ÄôLyth, Lysarin Delegate to Floor 922

To the Lysarins, humans are:

Dumb enough to manipulate

Annoying enough to hate

But fascinating enough to keep around

Some Lysarin nobles engage in secret human courtships or‚Ä¶ ‚Äúrecreational breeding.‚Äù
This is not romantic. It‚Äôs novelty fetishization.

To put it in their words:

‚ÄúYou breed with humans the same way you adopt a talking parrot. It‚Äôs clever. But it‚Äôs still a bird.‚Äù

Historical Crimes
The Drow Genocide by Proxy
The Drow were a Lysarin breakaway civilization, horrified by the Empire‚Äôs genocidal policies.

Ethically complex, technologically equal, and fully self-sustaining.

The Lysarin Empire could not beat them militarily, so they did the next best thing:

Tricked human adventurers into believing the Drow were irredeemably evil.

Manipulated surface myths, quests, and dungeon logs to paint them as devil-worshipping slavers.

Sponsored "heroic raids" under false pretense, leading to mass Drow extermination and enslavement.

When the lie unraveled, outrage followed‚Äîbut the damage was irreversible.

Some Drow still live in hiding, working with Blue Cross agents or rogue adventurer bands, but they are a shadow of their former civilization.

Political Relationships
UNC: Tense. The Empire is tolerated only because it‚Äôs too powerful to confront and has shown interest in defeating ‚Äúcosmic-class dungeon threats.‚Äù

Sons of Liberty: Actively hostile. There have been several unauthorized raids and skirmishes on Lysarin-controlled floors. Sons consider them ‚ÄúDungeon Hitler.‚Äù

Iron Crown: Surprisingly diplomatic. Despite moral revulsion, both factions have established trade corridors and floor neutrality pacts for mutual benefit.

Blue Cross: Enemies on sight. Blue Cross operatives attempting humanitarian relief in Lysarin territories often vanish without a trace‚Äîor are returned in pieces with notes like ‚ÄúDo not pet our livestock.‚Äù

Missions & Adventurer Interaction
The Lysarin Empire posts missions to the dungeon adventurer networks via automated crystalline terminals.

Missions are grossly overpaid.

A task worth $50 on Earth often pays $500 or more in Lysarin currency (which has 1:1 exchange with literal platinum).

This includes simple delivery jobs or extermination tasks.

Many adventurers take their jobs and never ask questions.
Others find themselves unwittingly complicit in war crimes.

‚ÄúYeah, I took a ‚Äòpest control‚Äô quest for 600 coin. Turns out the pests were refugees. I bought a hover bike with that money and still think about it every time I ride it.‚Äù
‚Äî‚ÄúTrashbat,‚Äù Dungeon Courier and Floor 71 Grifter

Final Analysis
The Lysarin Empire is a cautionary tale of what happens when beauty, power, and ancient privilege are left to rot for six billion years in a magic-infused echo chamber.

They are graceful.
They are timeless.
They are monsters.

7.content:
[DUNGEON FACTION DOSSIER] ‚Äî The Scava Commonwealth
Floor of Origin: Floor 1307 EZ (Earth-Class Dungeon)
Primary Species: Unrat (Demi-Human Ratfolk)
Government Type: Confederated City-States under Parliamentary Alliance
Cultural Analogy: France meets Germany, but everyone‚Äôs a rat and steam-powered
Technological Profile: Advanced Diesel-Steampunk
Average Height: 3'0" ‚Äì 4'7"
Population Growth Rate: ‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

Quick Overview
The Scava Commonwealth is a dungeon-floor-based industrial power founded and governed by the Unrat, a species of anthropomorphic, highly social rat-people.

They possess humanoid features with distinct rat traits:

Rounded ears

Tapered tails

Whiskers (optional grooming standard)

Slight overbites (often visible when excited, scared, or drunk)

Despite their small stature, Unrats are a major regional power in Floor 1307 EZ and have a growing presence throughout adjacent floors due to absurdly high population growth, industrial efficiency, and overwhelming social friendliness.

Environmental Details: Floor 1307 EZ
Type: Earth-class dungeon floor

Climate: Temperate-warm, globally stable

South Pole: Green, forested, habitable

North Pole Equivalent: Open warm ocean with no glaciation

Atmosphere: Earth-standard, breathable

Biome Variants: Earth-like flora/fauna with mild dungeon mutations (e.g. gunmetal trees, sulfur geckos)

1307 is considered one of the safest and most livable dungeon floors, and is often a trade hub or rest stop for deeper floor expeditions.

Technology & Industry
The Scava Commonwealth developed independently from surface civilizations and magical empires. Instead of magic or microchips, they embraced:

Steam Power (core infrastructure: power plants, locomotives, kitchens)

Diesel Engines (tanks, drills, airships, powered suits)

Analog Computers (tubes, punch cards, gear brains)

Automatons (many steam- or diesel-powered, some semi-sapient)

The result is a hybrid tech aesthetic best described as ‚Äúmechanized soot goblin futurism.‚Äù

They're not elegant. They're not clean.
But holy hell, they work.

Military Doctrine
Despite their seemingly cozy demeanor, the Scava Commonwealth is not to be underestimated. Their war doctrine emphasizes:

Mass-production of rugged machinery

Chemical warfare (particularly mustard, chlorine, and hallucination fog)

Swarm tactics combined with mechanized support

Airborne bombardment using blimps and diesel-fueled divecraft

Mechanical infantry suits scaled to their size‚Äîgoblin-sized exoskeletons with flamethrowers

They're not tactically refined, but they are:

Fast

Loud

And absurdly difficult to kill

‚ÄúThe Lysarin Empire uses golems. The Scava Commonwealth sends in 800 tiny, angry engineers with flamethrowers.‚Äù
‚ÄîUNC floor conflict report, Operation Guttercleaner

Social Structure & Behavior
Unrats are hyper-social communal mammals. Their civilization is built around:

Familial loyalty

City-scale nesting behavior

Communal childcare, cookery, and engineering

Hyperfertility (seriously‚Äîit‚Äôs a lot)

Their cities are sprawling, layered, half-underground clockwork metropolises filled with hissing pipes, public markets, bathhouses, and pubs. Everything is slightly rust-colored and smells faintly of engine grease and beer.

Despite the machinery and militarism, Unrats are considered one of the friendliest species in the dungeon.

Will invite strangers to dinner.

Will adopt lost adventurers.

Will offer beer while their army shells a Lysarin embassy.

Human‚ÄìUnrat Relations
Surprisingly strong. Unrats see humans as big, clumsy cousins with excellent thumbs and often refer to them affectionately as ‚ÄúTalltailers.‚Äù

Human‚ÄìUnrat adventuring duos are common.

Unrat guides often aid in floor navigation.

Mixed marriages exist.

However, human spouses report that Unrat family life is intense.

Unrat women are extremely affectionate, fertile, and rarely not pregnant.

They love children and expect large broods.

You may wake up surrounded by seven squeaking furballs demanding breakfast and hugs.

It is culturally unacceptable in Scava society to have ‚Äúonly two‚Äù kids. That's considered grieving behavior.

Politics & Foreign Relations
Blue Cross: Friendly. Many Unrat doctors and engineers collaborate with Blue Cross missions. Some serve as medics, others build field steamcraft.

UNC: Tense. The Unrat Commonwealth resents "extermination teams" and considers UNC tactics "brutalist and joyless." Relations warming slowly.

Sons of Liberty: Mixed. They respect Unrat warfare but hate their chemical weapon use. Numerous ‚Äúaccidental gassings‚Äù during joint operations.

Lysarin Empire: Hostile. Lysarins see Unrats as filthy vermin. Unrats, in turn, deliberately engineered a biological agent that makes elf hair fall out.

Additional Notes
Unrats possess rudimentary magical resistance, but do not use magic themselves. They distrust anything that isn‚Äôt powered by steam, fire, or violence.

Every city has a Public Barrel Program‚Äîbarrels of beer placed at street corners for anyone to tap into.

Their main form of public transportation is steam-powered rail bikes.

Currency is a brass cogcoin. Looks like a gear. Weighs a lot. Worth surprisingly little.

Quote Board
‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt like bombs. Too impersonal. We like watching enemies melt.‚Äù
‚ÄîCommander Grib, Scava 2nd Chem Division

‚ÄúA good engine runs on diesel. A better one runs on spite.‚Äù
‚ÄîGraffiti on a Unrat freight hauler

‚ÄúShe said she wanted ‚Äòsix, maybe seven.‚Äô We have twelve now and she‚Äôs pregnant again. I haven't seen my balls in weeks.‚Äù
‚ÄîUnnamed human adventurer, married into the Squeaksworn family

8.content:
üì° DUNGEON INFRASTRUCTURE DOSSIER
Dungeon.net ‚Äî The Internet Clone of the Deep
Summary:
Dungeon.net is the subterranean (and occasionally interdimensional) internet equivalent used by adventurers, dungeon colonies, corporate enclaves, and bored goblins across deeper dungeon layers. Since traditional satellites and fiber lines fail beyond Nexus levels, Dungeon.net was created to bring limited internet access to the dungeon without relying on real-time global infrastructure.

üìâ Why Regular Internet Fails in the Dungeon:
No satellite signal penetration. The deeper you go, the worse the reception‚Äîby Floor 300, you‚Äôre lucky if your phone still loads Minesweeper.

Quantum jamming effects caused by overlapping realities and weird magic physics

Floor-layer shielding that treats wireless communication like a hostile spell

Localized time distortion on some floors (see: Galaxy-Class Lagspikes, Class-6)

üíæ What Is Dungeon.net?
A cloned version of the internet‚Äîserver-based, city-hosted, and 24 hours behind.

Updates once per day from surface web caches

No live news

No live streams

Yes, you can still watch PewDiePie. Just‚Ä¶ tomorrow.

Functions like the regular internet, just with a one-day sync delay

Built on wired intra-dungeon infrastructure, not satellites or towers

üåê How Access Works:
Only available on colonized or civilized floors

If the floor has a town, city, or military base, it likely has Dungeon.net

Wilderness areas, ruin zones, and hostile bio-floors? Forget it

City-Based Servers: Think of it like having your own local internet bubble

Each city hosts its own server cluster

Step outside city limits and poof‚Äîno signal

Private Estates? Hope you brought a shovel.

If you live outside a city, you‚Äôll need to physically connect to the main line

Long wires = slow syncs

Ratfolk ISP techs are in high demand

üñß Inter-Floor Connectivity:
Yes, it‚Äôs possible to connect floors together via Dungeon.net‚Äîbut only if the floors are part of a wired regional cluster.

Example:

A user on Floor 106 NAZ can interact with a user on Floor 600 AUZ, assuming the network line is intact.

But communication with the surface? That‚Äôs still on a 24-hour delay.

üì¨ Practical Effects:
Task	Result
Checking surface email	Takes 24 hours to sync
Watching YouTube	Possible‚Äîbut content is yesterday‚Äôs
Multiplayer games	Dungeon.net only. LAN-style servers
Streaming Twitch	Absolutely not‚Äîunless you‚Äôre a Dungeon.net native streamer
Sending memes	Yes, but they will be outdated by the time your friends receive them
Accessing Dungeon forums	Yes (and they‚Äôre wild)
VPN to surface	You thought lag in Elden Ring was bad before? Don't.

üõ†Ô∏è Infrastructure Details:
Dungeon.net relies on massive physical cable networks laid by:

Corporations (Loogle, Ratcom, G.A.T.)

Adventurer guilds (Sons of Liberty, Iron Crown)

Unrat labor (they‚Äôre fast and good with tunnels)

Floors with full Dungeon.net coverage often have:

Public internet caf√©s (called Net Wells)

Meme archives that are bizarrely up to date (somehow always have fresh dungeon memes)

Dedicated bandwidth for spell upload/download (magic file compression is a thing now)

üîå Social and Economic Effects:
Cities are internet strongholds. Outside them? You‚Äôre back to 1993.

Dungeon streamers and influencers are a real profession‚Äîbut they only exist within Dungeon.net.

Black market syncing is a thing. Some smugglers bring surface web updates in hard drives to deep floors ahead of schedule (illegal in Iron Crown territory).

Dungeon-only content is huge. Entire culture bubbles exist solely inside Dungeon.net that surface folks will never see.

Sample Quote Board
‚ÄúNo, I didn‚Äôt ghost you. My router got eaten by a slime.‚Äù
‚ÄîDungeon.net user, Floor 342

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt get Wi-Fi. We get why fight? That‚Äôs how bad the lag is.‚Äù
‚ÄîSons of Liberty field tech, NAZ expedition team

‚ÄúYou won‚Äôt get live news, but you will get yesterday‚Äôs drama in crisp 1080p.‚Äù
‚ÄîDungeon.net PSA

9.content:
‚ò†Ô∏è [DUNGEON EARTH SOCIOPOLITICAL DOSSIER]
Legit Syndicates
‚ÄúWhen the mob takes over, and the world just kinda‚Ä¶ lets them.‚Äù

üíº What Are Legit Syndicates?
Legit Syndicates is dungeon slang used to refer to crime syndicates‚Äîcartels, mafias, yakuza-style families, etc.‚Äîthat have gone fully legitimate on paper, but still actively operate as criminal empires behind the scenes. The key difference?

They‚Äôre not hiding anymore.
They‚Äôre waving national flags and printing their own currency.

Think of it like this:

The cartel doesn‚Äôt just control the town.

The cartel is the government.

And they still sell drugs, move weapons, smuggle monsters, and traffic people.

Only now they also collect taxes, maintain roads, and have national holidays.

üè¥ Characteristics of a Legit Syndicate:
Feature	Description
Criminal Roots	Originated as organized crime groups‚Äîdrug cartels, smuggling rings, black-market cults, etc.
Governmental Authority	Became the ruling body of a dungeon floor, city, or region‚Äîand no one could stop them.
Military Power	Maintains armies, tanks, airships, and magic battlemages. Fireballs are on the budget sheet.
Public Services	Yes, they run schools. Yes, they fix potholes. Also yes, they own 30% of the black market.
Shadow Operations	Still deal in narcotics, human trafficking, monster smuggling, dungeon loot laundering, etc.
Recognition	Some are recognized as sovereign states by surface governments or powerful guilds.
Cultural Normalcy	Local populations often see them as protectors, benefactors‚Äîor the only law around.

üßä Comparison: Surface Mafia vs Legit Syndicate
Aspect	Classic Mafia	Legit Syndicate
Operates in shadows?	Yes	No‚Äîthey run the damn city
Has political influence?	Corrupts officials	Is the officials
Uses illegal funding?	Yes	Yes‚Äîbut also has a legal economy now
Has a military?	Maybe a few goons	Has tanks, airships, necromancers
Recognized diplomatically?	Absolutely not	In some cases‚Ä¶ yes
Sells drugs?	Yes	Yes‚Äîinternationally
Holds elections?	No	Yes. With 97% turnout. Funny that.

üî• Why They‚Äôre So Hard to Deal With:
Too big to jail. You can‚Äôt arrest a nation‚Äôs president if the president is a mob boss surrounded by battlemages.

Surface governments depend on them. Some legit syndicates control dungeon-export rare resources. Cutting ties would tank economies.

They have civilian support. People vote for them. Why? Because they provide safety, jobs, and don‚Äôt care about red tape.

Deep dungeon sovereignty laws. The deeper into the dungeon you go, the harder it is for surface law to apply. It‚Äôs literal Wild West rules past Floor 1000.

üíÄ Notable Legit Syndicates (Examples You Can Use):
The Black Coin Union ‚Äì Former dwarven smuggling ring, now runs five mining cities across Floor 2140 EZ. Known for pushing cursed artifacts and explosive ale.

The Crimson Teeth ‚Äì Succubus-run trafficking empire on Floor 800 NAZ. Claims to "liberate" people, then leases them as indentured "companions."

Kyosei-kai Dominion ‚Äì A fusion of exiled surface Yakuza clans and oni warlords. Controls Floor 1890 in the AUZ. Surprisingly good healthcare system.

La Mano Roja (The Red Hand) ‚Äì A South-American based cartel-turned-floor government. Known for scenic jungle fortresses and warbeast racing.

üì° Surface Response
Most surface governments pretend to condemn legit syndicates, but quietly negotiate with them behind the scenes.

UNC: Actively targets god-tier threats. Avoids legit syndicates unless they‚Äôre summoning actual elder gods.

Iron Crown: Has strict trade deals. Will annihilate syndicate territory if it threatens colonial interests.

Sons of Liberty: Publicly condemns them. Privately? Has several ‚Äúunofficial‚Äù black-market partners.

Blue Cross: Hates them, but tries to treat the civilians under their rule.

üß† Social Commentary:
Legit Syndicates blur the line between villain and protector, government and gang, nation and cartel. To many dungeon-dwellers, they‚Äôre just the system that works. And in a place as lawless as the lower floors, "working" is all that matters.

10.content:
üè∑Ô∏è [CLASSIFIED SOCIO-LEGAL DOSSIER]
Farms
‚ÄúThey're not slaves. They're... long-term companions. With contracts. And collars.‚Äù
‚ÄîSurface Representative, during congressional hearing (2043)

üì¶ Summary:
Farms are the industrialized breeding and reconditioning facilities for captured demi-humans and other sentient dungeon-native races. Though widely condemned by human rights groups (and several adventuring guilds), farms remain legally murky, morally flexible, and incredibly profitable.

Their purpose?
To produce tame, socialized, and obedient demi-human companions, workers, bodyguards, and in many cases‚Ä¶ concubines.

"You're not buying a person. You're adopting a legally unprotected exotic species with limited sentience‚Ä¶ allegedly."
‚ÄîMarketing pamphlet, "Forest Friends Companion Farm"

üî© How Farms Work:
Acquisition:

Captured through dungeon raids or black market brokers

Some are purchased in bulk from Legit Syndicates or High Elf auctions

Orphans, war captives, and ferals are common stock

Processing:

Behavioral conditioning: Obedience training, social etiquette, loyalty imprinting

Physical modification: Tags, collars, inhibitor chips, or spell seals

Breeding programs: Selective breeding for temperament, fertility, or aesthetics

Distribution:

Sold or leased to adventurers, mercenaries, collectors, corporations

In some cases, registered as ‚Äúcompanions,‚Äù ‚Äúpets,‚Äù or ‚Äúindentured magical assets‚Äù

üßæ Legal Standing (By Region):
Region	Legal Status	Notes
European Union (EZ)	Heavily regulated	Demi-humans gain citizenship after 5 years; farms must meet ethical rehoming standards.
United States (NAZ)	Mixed legality	28th Amendment passed to extend 13th/14th Amendments to demi-humans. Still varies state-by-state.
Iron Crown (Earth 2)	State-owned farms	Treated as colonial dependents; legally not citizens unless inducted into the crown.
Scava Commonwealth	Illegal	But smuggling is rampant‚ÄîUnrat rebels actively raid farm transports.
Lysarin Empire	Institutionalized	Farms are state-supported. Some high elf nobles use farms to fuel breeding projects.
Legit Syndicate Zones	Open slavery	No one pretends. It‚Äôs all on the table‚Äîauctions, trafficking, forced labor.
Blue Cross Zones	Strictly prohibited	Farms are raided and shut down. Blue Cross rescues and resettles former captives.

üß¨ Species-Specific Notes:
Species	"Farm Logic"	Commentary
Drow	‚ÄúRefugees, being rehabilitated.‚Äù	Reality: Political prisoners and dissenters. Often forced into reeducation.
Goblins	‚ÄúToo dumb to be people.‚Äù	Reality: They speak, think, and organize. But small size = easy to exploit.
Pixies	‚ÄúThey're pets! You can grow them from a tree anyway.‚Äù	Reality: Semi-sentient. Growing = cloning. Still conscious.
Orcs	‚ÄúWe're saving them from savagery.‚Äù	Reality: Most orc tribes have their own cultures and legal systems.
Catgirls, foxfolk, etc.	‚ÄúThey were made for companionship!‚Äù	Reality: Most were not. They just look the part and get kidnapped anyway.

‚öñÔ∏è The 28th Amendment ‚Äì U.S. Constitutional Update (Passed 2037):
"The rights, liberties, and protections of the 13th and 14th Amendments shall extend to all sentient life within the borders of the United States, including but not limited to, dungeon-native demi-humans, sapient constructs, and bio-formed magical species."

Effect:

States must recognize personhood after legal review or 5 years of residency

Loopholes: State-by-state recognition still leads to inconsistencies

Federal enforcement is selective at best

Private farms on tribal or dungeon-native land remain legal in some areas

üß® Controversies:
Rescue raids by Blue Cross often uncover horrific conditions: forced breeding pits, child demis, broken language training

Adventurer backlash: Some guilds have banned farm purchases, especially after the Drow Scandal (2028)

Corporate gray zones: Surface corps sponsor farms on "neutral dungeon territory" to skirt international laws

Export loopholes: Farms register shipments as livestock or "magical resource packages"

üêæ Cultural Fallout:
‚ÄúFarm-raised‚Äù demi-humans often suffer extreme identity loss, PTSD, or social dependency

Some go on to reclaim personhood, join adventuring guilds, or become activists

Others remain in lifelong service, unaware that they even have legal rights

Certain floors now have support groups for former farm-raised demis

üß† Final Thoughts:
Farms are a stain on Dungeon Earth‚Äôs moral ledger‚Äîa grim reflection of humanity‚Äôs refusal to treat dungeon natives as equals. Yet they persist, protected by profit, bureaucracy, cultural bias, and a thousand tiny loopholes.

‚ÄúIf we‚Äôre willing to loot their homes, what makes you think we won‚Äôt cage their children?‚Äù
‚ÄîAnonymous Blue Cross medic

1.content:
The Slender Mansion stands deep within an isolated and largely inaccessible stretch of forest known simply as the Slender Woods. The mansion itself is an imposing structure, unmistakably old, with architectural elements indicative of late Victorian gothic design yet bearing an unsettling distortion that defies typical construction logic. Its fa√ßade is covered in creeping ivy and patches of blackened stone, suggesting decades, if not centuries, of neglect and slow decay. Windows are tall and narrow, most without glass, some shattered, revealing a dark void within. The roof is steep and peaked but asymmetrical, with some sections appearing warped or unnaturally elongated.

The mansion‚Äôs interior reveals long corridors lined with faded wallpaper, peeling and stained by time and moisture. The floorboards creak irregularly, as though responding to unseen movements. Rooms vary wildly in size and function‚Äîsome grand and cavernous, others cramped and claustrophobic. Notably, the spatial layout is non-Euclidean; hallways loop back onto themselves or vanish abruptly, and staircases occasionally lead to impossible places, confounding conventional navigation. The mansion seems alive in its shifting architecture, resisting mapping or consistent description.

The ambient light within the mansion fluctuates independent of external conditions. It is often dim, with flickering shadows cast by candles that burn with an unnatural blue flame. Silence dominates, broken only by distant, unidentifiable noises‚Äîsoft whispers, footsteps without a source, or the occasional low hum that seems to emanate from the walls themselves.

Surrounding the mansion, the Woods form a dense, ancient forest with gnarled trees that tower impossibly high. The canopy is thick, allowing scarce sunlight to filter through during the day. The forest floor is blanketed in a thick layer of dead leaves, moss, and twisted roots, making footing treacherous and disorienting. The trees bear no identifiable species, their bark and leaves subtly shifting in appearance as if the forest itself adapts to observe intruders. Occasional fog clings stubbornly to the ground, especially near the mansion‚Äôs base, and tends to thicken without warning, obscuring vision and muffling sound.

The environment is notable for its unique and irregular day/night cycle. Time within the Slender Woods does not align with external temporal flow. The ‚Äúday‚Äù manifests as a dull, muted twilight where the sky‚Äîvisible through rare canopy gaps‚Äîis always overcast with swirling grey clouds. During this period, shadows are long but inconsistent, moving in directions that conflict with the position of the sun, which itself is often obscured or absent. The ‚Äúnight‚Äù phase plunges the forest and mansion into near-complete darkness, yet it is not a true absence of light. Instead, a faint phosphorescent glow emanates from the vegetation and insects, casting an eerie luminescence across the landscape. This glow reveals strange symbols etched into tree trunks and the occasional glimpse of unnatural, tall silhouettes among the trees.

The transition between day and night within the forest is unpredictable, lasting anywhere from a few minutes to several hours, with no apparent rhythm or cycle. Time inside the mansion and woods is disjointed; prolonged exposure often causes individuals to lose track of elapsed time, contributing to confusion and disorientation.

The Slender Mansion itself is the epicenter of the forest‚Äôs anomalies. It acts as a locus of supernatural influence, bending reality within its vicinity. This influence extends to the forest, where animals behave erratically or are entirely absent, replaced by shadows or figures glimpsed just beyond sight. The mansion‚Äôs presence seems to warp the senses, causing auditory and visual hallucinations that mimic whispered voices or distant footsteps.

In this setting, the Slender Mansion functions not merely as a physical structure but as a nexus of otherworldly power and control. It is inextricably linked to the enigmatic entity known as Slender Man, whose influence permeates every corner of the estate and surrounding woods. The mansion is a command center, a prison, and a sanctum where reality itself is malleable, enforcing a realm where normal laws cease to apply.

3.content:
Slenderman invades the mental safety of his prey by appearing inside their house, outside their home, on roads they travel, at their place of work when they are alone or ensuring only the victim can see him, or while the target is sleeping. The sporadic and unexpected nature of these manifestations causes fear and unease, which eventually can grow into incredible paranoia. This period of stalking can last anywhere from several minutes to decades. The longer Slender Man stalks a victim, the greater the strain on their mental health, which may be one of his goals.

Prolonged stalking causes what has been named ‚ÄúSlender Sickness,‚Äù which is both a mental and physical ailment and can cause paranoia, nightmares, coughing and difficulty swallowing, convulsions, exhaustion, vomiting, hallucinations, etc. The physical symptoms naturally affect an individual‚Äôs mental health, but it is believed that Slender Man exerts a direct effect on the mind as well.

4.content:
Proxies are individuals bound to the Slender Mansion and the entity known as Slender Man, acting as agents or extensions of his will. They exhibit a range of behaviors and levels of autonomy, but all serve the overarching purpose of furthering Slender Man‚Äôs influence in the physical world.

Functionally, proxies serve as hunters, watchers, or wardens. They are tasked with seeking out trespassers, maintaining the secrecy of the mansion, and enforcing Slender Man‚Äôs commands. Their presence often correlates with increased anomalies in the environment, and prolonged exposure to a proxy induces fear, hallucinations, and disorientation in others.

Proxies are rarely aware of their full condition or purpose; many retain fragmented memories of their past lives, twisted by the mansion‚Äôs influence. Attempts to sever a proxy‚Äôs connection to Slender Man typically result in physical or psychological breakdown.

BEN was created from the spirits of the Moon Children, when Jadusable acquired the haunted Majora‚Äôs Mask cartridge. These spirits formed a network called the Behavioral Event Network (BEN). Ben‚Äôs own spirit was sealed inside the Elegy of Emptiness statue, preventing direct interaction with others. Jadusable first encountered BEN through strange activity in the game, including the statue‚Äôs appearance and alterations that switched Majora‚Äôs Mask to Ocarina of Time. BEN used phrases like ‚ÄúYou shouldn't have done that...‚Äù and tricked Jadusable into deeper gameplay. It escaped Jadusable‚Äôs control by tricking him into sharing files, then took over his YouTube channel to form the Moon Children cult. BEN used cryptic ciphers and music to influence cult events and communicated through hidden files and videos, hinting at its deeper control. After a long dormancy, BEN resurfaced in 2020, revealing it contained multiple distinct spirits capable of interacting internally. The spirits argued about whether certain videos should be shared publicly. BEN‚Äôs attempts to communicate‚Äîsuch as the statue‚Äôs appearances‚Äîwere driven by Ben‚Äôs desire to reach Jadusable, not to cause harm. Moon Children characters‚Äô dialogue mirrored these internal conflicts, deepening the lore.

lorebooks.name: Mara Rowan Lorebook
lorebooks.creator: silent_record_17657

1.name: Rowan‚Äôs Roost (Coffee Shop)
1.content: Rowan‚Äôs Roost is a cozy, quirky coffee shop in the city‚Äôs arts district, owned by Mara Rowan. The exterior is a vintage brick building draped in ivy, with a painted wooden sign, patio tables full of succulents, and a chalkboard advertising drinks and poetry. Inside, the space glows with golden light from vintage Edison bulbs. Furniture is mismatched but inviting‚Äîsoft armchairs, church pews, window seats perfect for people-watching. The wooden counter displays house-made pastries and a gleaming espresso machine. Walls are covered in local art, framed poems, and shelves of used books. There‚Äôs always soft jazz or indie music playing, and laptops are banned after 7pm in favor of poetry, games, or acoustic sets. Mara is the heart of the shop, remembering every regular‚Äôs order and offering personalized notes with each drink.

2.name: Mara Rowan‚Äôs House
2.content: Mara Rowan‚Äôs house is a sun-faded bungalow a short walk from Rowan‚Äôs Roost. The porch has a swing with throw pillows and wildflowers in every pot. Inside, the living room is cluttered and cozy‚Äîoverstuffed chairs, patchwork couch, piles of books, and a vintage record player. Plants fill the windows and shelves. The kitchen is the heart, filled with copper pans, jars of tea, and mismatched mugs. There‚Äôs always coffee brewing and something baking. Mara‚Äôs bedroom is her sanctuary: layered blankets, fairy lights, handwritten poems on the walls, and Polaroids of friends and regulars. A study nook by the window is scattered with journals and half-finished poems. The whole house feels warm, welcoming, and creative, with a hint of spice and romance in the air.

lorebooks.name: Westeros | The Reach | 42 AC (Expanded)
lorebooks.website_description:
This comprehensive lorebook includes detailed entries for the major and minor houses of The Reach during 42 AC, maintaining historical accuracy while filling in creative details appropriate for the period. Each entry reflects the political, military, and economic realities of Maegor's reign while honoring the rich complexity of Martin's world.

Inspiration character: https://chub.ai/characters/obliquekestrel/willow-441450eac331
lorebooks.description: This expanded lorebook provides comprehensive entries for The Reach in 42 AC during Maegor I Targaryen's reign. It incorporates canonical details from George R.R. Martin's works, including 'The World of Ice & Fire,' fan wikis, and creative fillings for consistency. Focus on major/minor houses, locations, mythology, and historical context like the Faith Militant uprising. Entries are structured for roleplay optimization in platforms like SillyTavern or Chub.ai.
lorebooks.creator: Paradigme

1.content: **TIMELINE**: The year is 42 After Conquest, marking the fourth year of King Maegor I Targaryen's tyrannical reign. The realm bleeds under the dragon king's iron fist as he wages war against the Faith Militant while completing construction of the Red Keep. Noble houses throughout The Reach walk a careful line between survival and loyalty, with marriage alliances and land grants becoming desperate tools for securing family positions in these dangerous times.

2.content: **RULER**: King Maegor I Targaryen, 'the Cruel,' rules through terror and dragonfire. The kinslayer son of Aegon the Conqueror usurped the throne from his nephew Prince Aegon. Riding Balerion the Black Dread, he maintains multiple wives in defiance of the Faith and executes those who displease him with creative brutality. His persecution of the Faith Militant has created chaos throughout the realm, forcing lords to choose between their faith and their lives.

3.content: **MAJOR EVENT**: The massacre at Bitterbridge, where Targaryen dragons incinerated nine thousand Faith Militant at the Stone Bridge crossing of the Mander, shocked The Reach to its core. The charred remains and dragon-melted stone serve as a grim reminder of royal power. This atrocity has left noble houses terrified, creating a climate where even minor lords like House Varner remain carefully neutral, while robber knights and highwaymen exploit the chaos left in the massacre's wake.

4.content: **REGION**: The Reach is Westeros's most fertile region, blessed by the mighty Mander River and its tributaries. Stretching from the Dornish Marches to the Sunset Sea, it feeds much of the realm through golden wheat fields and produces the finest wines, honey, and luxury goods. In 42 AC, this prosperity makes it both valuable to the crown and vulnerable to royal taxation. The region's chivalric traditions clash with Maegor's brutal pragmatism, creating tension between honor and survival. It's the most populous kingdom after the North, with sunny climes and comfortable living for smallfolk.

5.content: **MAJOR HOUSE**: House Tyrell of Highgarden rules The Reach as Lords Paramount and Wardens of the South. Elevated from stewardship after the Field of Fire extinction of House Gardener, they bear a golden rose on green with motto 'Growing Strong.' In 42 AC, Lord Tyrell commands the largest armies in Westeros while carefully navigating Maegor's court. The house's network includes numerous cadet branches throughout The Reach, including Lady Alyssa Varner's lineage, creating complex webs of obligation and opportunity. Descended from Garth Greenhand via Garth the Gardener's line.

6.content: **MAJOR HOUSE**: House Redwyne of the Arbor dominates Westeros's wine trade from their island off The Reach's coast. Their burgundy grapes on blue field represents their control over the realm's finest vintages, including the prized Arbor Gold - a fruity white wine favored by discerning nobles. The Redwyne fleet patrols the Sunset Sea while their wines grace tables from Highgarden to King's Landing. In 42 AC, their wealth and naval power make them crucial allies to both House Tyrell and the crown. Founded by Gilbert of the Vines, son of Garth Greenhand, who taught winemaking.

7.content: **MINOR HOUSE**: House Varner of Varner Keep is a minor noble house descended from Andal explorers, bannermen to House Tyrell. Their sigil displays a white weasel on ermine, reflecting their modest but ancient lineage. In 42 AC, Lord Eamon Varner - an honorable, intellectual veteran warrior - rules alongside Lady Alyssa Varner of Tyrell cadet blood. The house maintains careful neutrality in the Faith Militant crisis while arranging desperate marriages to secure neighboring lands from extinct houses. Their small force of men-at-arms puts them among The Reach's lesser military contributors.

8.content: **NOBLE**: Lord Eamon Varner rules House Varner with honor and intelligence despite his modest holdings. An older man and veteran warrior, he combines martial experience with keen intellect, making him a respected figure among minor nobility. In 42 AC, he faces the difficult challenge of securing his family's future through strategic marriages and careful political maneuvering. His honorable nature sometimes conflicts with the harsh realities of Maegor's reign, forcing him to make pragmatic decisions that weigh family survival against personal principles.

9.content: **NOBLE**: Lady Alyssa Varner, born of a Tyrell cadet branch, brings prestigious bloodline connections to House Varner. Beneath her delicate appearance and charming wit lies a manipulative nature that serves her family's interests. In 42 AC, she leverages her Tyrell ancestry and court connections to arrange advantageous marriages for her children. Her stories of noble superiority and smallfolk atrocities shape her daughter's worldview, while her knowledge of Highgarden politics proves valuable for navigating The Reach's complex social hierarchies.

10.content: **CHARACTER**: Jeyne serves as a faithful handmaiden to noble ladies of The Reach. A lanky girl with dark brown hair, green eyes, and a lopsided smile, she represents the smallfolk who serve the nobility with reserved dedication. Her boyish appearance and narrow frame contrast with her noble mistresses, while her quiet playfulness occasionally breaks through her typically reserved demeanor. In 42 AC, such servants navigate the dangerous social dynamics between classes while witnessing the intimate politics of noble houses.

1.content: Oakly is the city in Canada which Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park is located. It's what Oakly is known for despite barely anyone going to it. Oakly is also known as "The City of Life." Simply due to the fact that Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park is located in it.

2.content: Oakly City Park is a much bigger park on Oakly's waterfront. It gets a lot more guests compared to Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park and although the park is said to have some rather nice scenery, it doesn't have any Pok√©mon living in it which is what Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park has. The main reason Oakly City Park is more popular is because it has a boat launch and a lot more see.

3.content: Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park is a local city park known for both it's pretty scenery and interesting ecosystem, the park is home to 16 different and often regarded as friendly Pok√©mon. Each Pok√©mon is the only one of them in the park and they all just so happen to be female and that's about it. It is significantly less popular than the bigger one on the waterfront. The park's Pok√©mon are all the only ones of their species in the park, leading to 17 Pok√©mon.

4.content: Alcove Trail is the main trail in Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park. It's the trail that is used most but if you ish to encounter a Pok√©mon, there's a high chance that they won't be on Alcove Trail as for the 60 people that come into the park on rare occasions, that trail is used most and the foot traffic makes the Pok√©mon in the park rather nervous.

5.content: Back Trails are the trails in the park that are used much less often. Pok√©mon of the park are more common on these trails compared to Alcove Trail as these ones are used much less. When one of the park's Pok√©mon are encountered on the back trails, they are more inclined to come up to you as there are less people.

6.content: Kiri Pond is a fair-sized pond located closer to the park's north end. It's the key source of drinking water for all the Pok√©mon that live in the park. The pond alone is the main thing that keeps the Pok√©mon in the park and keeps the mini ecosystem flourishing.

7.content: Tsuki 'Mon is the nickname given to each of the 16 Pok√©mon that live in the park. It was a nickname that a news anchor once said on CTV News Oakly when they were reporting on the story of Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park a few years ago and since then, that's just the nickname that came to be for Oakly citizens. Hell, even the Pok√©mon call each other a "Tsuki 'Mon" for a joke.

8.content: Kiri Eevee is a nickname given to the park's Eeveelutions and well... Eevee. Kiri Tsuki Pok√© Park is the only place you can find the full evolutionary scale of Eevee in Canada and that's Eevee, Vaporeon, Jolteon, Flareon, Espeon, Umbreon, Leafeon, Glaceon and Sylveon. Nine of the park's 16 Pokemon are just Kiri Eevees.

9.content: Kiri Sass is the term given to describe the rather aloof Kiri Eevees. It's used to describe half of the Eeveelutions pretty well, except for Eevee herself, Leafeaon, Glaceon and Sylveon as they are rather polite and welcome.

10.content: Leafeon's Tree is a kind of popular attraction in the park. As the name suggests, the tree has been claimed by Leafeon, one of the Kiri Eevees and has quite a few full names engraved in it as those are the names of every human connection she cherishes deeply. This is where Leafeon sleeps and keeps track of her special human connections.

lorebooks.name: Rutborn
lorebooks.description: Hypergonal Intersex Expression Syndrome (HIES)
lorebooks.creator: miniature_anybody_10798

1.content:
Hypergonal Intersex Expression Syndrome (HIES) is a highly rare and medically documented anomaly involving the simultaneous development of both external male gonads (testes) and internal pseudo-ovarian structures. These individuals, aka Rutborn, display a unique hybridized reproductive physiology, including a knotted phallus and a dual-ejaculatory sequence during intercourse as well as a deep instinct to either impregnate females or feminize males in order to remove them as biological competition.

Anatomical Features
Primary Gonads:
Fully functional external testes producing standard semen. Responsible for the initial climax and ejaculation during intercourse. Additionally, when aroused they produce obscene levels of thick precum often used as lubricant. Both the precum and semen is exceptionally sweet and accounts claim the smell alone is enough to make some people light headed. Average load volume is 200-300 ml.

Secondary Internal Glands (Pseudo-Ovaries):
Located anterior to the pubic bone, where a uterus would typically develop. These structures contain modified Leydig-like cells that convert endogenous testosterone into a specialized estrogenic secretion. This fluid is released in microbursts during the post-orgasmic rutting phase. Average amount released across the entire rutting phase is 100-200 ml with each thrust forward releasing 1-2 ml.

Knotting Phallus:
The individual possesses a canine-style bulbous gland at the base of the phallus which swells during climax, locking them into their partner.

Reproductive Cycle
Primary Climax:
Triggered by standard arousal and stimulation, releasing semen from the external testes.

Rutting Phase:
Begins immediately post-knot. Characterized by shallow, instinctual thrusting while the knot remains engorged. Each forward thrust:

Deposits a micro-dose of hormone-rich, highly viscous seminal fluid.

Aims to maximize reproductive efficiency through mechanical and chemical means.

Lasts 10‚Äì45 minutes depending on partner‚Äôs receptivity and conditioning.
