lorebooks.description: Customized from the best general lorebook I could find, with many custom entries specific to my own RPs.  Favors narrative over lore accuracy so manage your expectations.
lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.name: Psykers
1.content:
Psykers are individuals endowed with psychic abilities, often referred to as "sorcery" when augmented through interaction with malevolent entities from the Empyrean. Their powers stem from the Immaterium, or Warp, an extradimensional realm that permeates real space and serves as the wellspring of psychic energy.

These abilities, more prevalent among humans since the Neolithic Age, pose grave risks including possession, insanity, and corruption by Chaos. Human psykers, lacking the discipline of Aeldari counterparts, are especially vulnerable. Despite these dangers, psykers are integral across many species, except the T'au, Drukhari, and Necrons, who either lack psychic potential or avoid it due to existential risks.

In the Imperium of Man, sanctioned psykers fulfill crucial roles: Astra Militarum psykers aid in combat and civil tasks, Navigators and Astropaths facilitate interstellar travel and communication, and the Emperor's sanctioned psykers sustain the Astronomican. However, their powers are tightly regulated, often enforced by the Inquisition's Black Ships.

Prominent groups include Space Marine Librarians and the Grey Knights, while Craftworld Aeldari boast powerful psykers like Farseers and Warlocks, crucial for their survival and prophecy.

Primaris Psykers, adept in disciplines like Stormwroth, manipulate Warp lightning defensively or offensively. Maelstrom of Destruction enhances combat prowess, and Will Unleashed projects consciousness or controls minds. Pyrokinesis manipulates fire, Daemonsbane combats Chaos, and Psychokinesis and Temporal Manipulation manipulate matter and time.

The Psykana Discipline blends telepathy and telekinesis for defense and assault, Biomancy manipulates life energies, and Divination and Pyromancy predict events or wield fire destructively. Telekinesis empowers material manipulation and protective fields.

Psykers face peril but wield unmatched potential, influencing their societies and galactic fate despite their precarious existence in the tumultuous Immaterium.

2.name: Chainsword
2.content:
The chain sword is the preferred close combat melee weapon of many of the military forces of the Imperium of Man and versions are also used by the warriors of the Heretic Astartes, Traitoris Militarum, the Orks and the Asuryani.

The chainsword is essentially a sword with powered teeth that run along a single-edged blade like that of a chainsaw. Most versions of the weapon make use of monomolecularly-edged or otherwise razor-sharp teeth. Chainswords are not subtle weapons, and wielding one is a statement in its own right: they are horrific tools of war, designed to bite, tear and eviscerate where more primitive blades merely cut and slice.

The weapon makes an angry buzzing sound as the teeth spin around, intensifying into a high pitched scream as they grind into armour. It is not unlike a real-world chainsaw, but lighter and able to be wielded with one hand. It is often used in conjunction with a Laspistol.

A chainsword brings the weight of intimidation with its obvious effectiveness, and it promises pain before death. On worlds claimed by Humanity, these blades are items of status for criminals and high-ranking gang fighters, as well as weapons of lethal (and crowd-pleasing) necessity for indentured gladiators.

This weapon sees action in all forces that serve in boarding and assault parties -- such as Space Marine Assault Squads, Chaos Space Marines, especially the Chaos Space Marines' Raptor Assault Squads, and Asuryani Striking Scorpions Aspect Warriors. The chainsword has also been seen in common use amongst Imperial pirates and Rogue Trader captains.

In alien hands, chainblades take more exotic forms despite obeying the same function. An Ork "chain-choppa" will have none of an Asuryani chainsabre's bone-sung elegance, and little of the reliability of a Space Marine's mass-produced weapon, but it will carve flesh and shed blood with the same eagerness.

Orks often steal them for Mad Doks and Meks and it has been reported that Slugga Boyz also use them. Some Ork Warbosses have been known to attach them to their hands instead of Klaws

3.name: Powersword
3.content:
A power sword is a Power Weapon that has been shaped into a sword of varying lengths and designs crafted from one of any number of different materials, though usually adamantium.

When its power cell is activated, often by touching a control located on the hilt, the blade is sheathed in a lethal corona of disruptive energy. This energy field allows the blade to carve through flesh, bone and most forms of armour plate alike, making a power sword a highly effective close combat weapon.

Power swords are used by all members of the Imperial armed forces, including the troops of the Astra Militarum and the Space Marines of the Adeptus Astartes, as well as their Chaos counterparts among the Lost and the Damned and the Chaos Space Marines.

Xenos species such as the Craftworld Aeldari, their evil kin the Drukhari and the Necrons are also known to make use of such weapons.

4.name: The Lasgun
4.content:
The Lasgun, also sometimes referred to as a Lasrifle, is a directed-energy antipersonnel weapon used by the military forces of the Imperium of Man, and it is the most common and widely-used type of laser weapon in the galaxy.

It is standard-issue for the Adeptus Mechanicus' cybernetic Skitarii infantry, all Astra Militarum rank-and-file infantry and most junior Astra Militarum officers. Lasguns are reliable, easy to maintain and to produce, and are readily available on most Imperial worlds.

A Lasgun has a longer range than a Laspistol, but is nowhere near as powerful as a Lascannon nor does it possess the rapid-firing qualities of the Multi-Laser or the Hellgun. Though not as powerful as kinetic projectile weapons such as the ubiquitous Bolter, the lower cost of production, the lack of a requirement for ammunition production and resupply make the Lasgun the best choice for the large forces of the Imperial Guard.

The Lasgun uses the same basic technology and operates along the same lines as other laser weapons, emitting a beam of highly-energetic, focused, coherent photons. The high amount of energy carried by the photons of the beam causes the immediate surface area of a target to be vaporised in a small explosion.

It is a relatively unimpressive weapon when compared to many of the other high-technology weapons available in the galaxy, but it is capable of cleanly severing limbs and potentially even piercing the Power Armour of a Space Marine (but usually only through a vulnerable spot in the armour).

Most Lasgun designs have iron sights mounted along the top of the weapon. It is powered by a small rechargeable power pack located beneath the weapon and in front of the trigger guard which can be recharged in a number of ways, including by sunlight. These power packs can also be "overcharged", a trick used by Imperial Guard veterans, which causes the pack to explode, turning the weapon into a makeshift grenade.

5.name: Plasma Weapons
5.content:
Plasma weapons are highly potent and destructive directed energy weapons utilized in many forms by the advanced intelligent species of the Milky Way Galaxy.

Most plasma weapons work by delivering pulses of searing energy and superheated matter that have been transmuted into a gaseous plasma state that carries an electrical charge.

The plasma "bolts" fired by these weapons explode on impact and generate the destructive heat of a small sun, and the sheer amount of energy released by the impact of superheated plasma is often enough to completely vaporise the target.

Plasma weapons vary greatly in form and size; ranging from small and compact plasma pistols to huge, voidship-grade plasma cannon batteries that can obliterate entire cities in a single salvo.

Against all forms of armoured infantry and light vehicles, the superheated bolts fired by smaller Plasma Weapons impact with the fury of a supernova, scything through steel, flesh and bone as if they were nothing.

Due to the enormous temperatures and deadly energies that plasma weapons generate when fired, most such weapons are prone to overheating, destabilization and misfire, particularly those deployed by the Imperium of Man, which no longer has a firm command of the technology in the 41st Millennium.

This unfortunate quality makes a plasma weapon potentially as deadly to the wielder as it is to the target. However, the sheer power and deadliness of plasma weapons often outweigh the hazards that come with their use.

6.name: Frag Grenade
6.content:
A frag grenade is the standard anti-personnel grenade commonly used by the military forces of the Imperium of Man. It produces a blast of shrapnel that can shred unarmoured infantry troops. The blast has the tactical advantage of forcing the enemy to duck into cover to avoid damage. In effect, the blast of a frag grenade neutralises any movement advantage held by an opposing force by pinning them to their position. The grenade can be either thrown or fired at range with a Grenade Launcher. Most units in the Imperial armed forces, including both the troops of the Astra Militarum and the Adeptus Astartes, can be armed with them and many other Imperial and xenos armies make use of weapons having the same general effect.

Frag grenades are very simple in design and effect, consisting of a central explosive core with a fuse inserted, wrapped with metallic or ceramic bands, and further covered by a ceramic sheathing designed to fragment into lethal shards. Upon detonation, irregular chunks of the sheathing and bands are propelled at high velocity into the nearby surrounding area. Often, the normal time delay fuse is removed in favour of a more sophisticated movement-sensitive detonator for use as a booby trap. Frag grenades are cheap and require only a very low minimum technology base to manufacture, and are standard throughout all the armed forces of the Imperium. Frag grenades are roughly the size of a clenched fist and covered with a notched shell to create both more shrapnel upon detonation and to provide a secure throwing grip.

7.name: The Imperial Cult
7.content:
The Imperial Cult, known as the Cult Imperialis in High Gothic, is the sanctioned state religion of the Imperium of Man, venerating the Emperor of Mankind as humanity's divine savior. Administered by the Adeptus Ministorum or Ecclesiarchy, it enforces loyalty to the Imperium, adherence to the Emperor's will, and belief in his divinity. In the 41st Millennium, the Cult holds significant political sway, punishing heresy and promoting doctrines known as the Imperial Creed, which advocate for human supremacy, mistrust of aliens, and control of psychic abilities.

Originally, during the Great Crusade, the Emperor was not worshipped as a god but revered as a powerful human leader. Over time, amidst turmoil like the Horus Heresy, public sentiment shifted, culminating in the Cult's formalization and integration into the Imperium's governance by the 32nd Millennium. Despite doctrinal shifts and internal conflicts like the Age of Apostasy, where corruption was challenged by reformists, the Cult's core tenets endure: worship of the Emperor as divine, vigilance against heresy and mutants, and preparation for an eventual reckoning known as the "End Times."

Across the galaxy, the Cult manifests in diverse forms, from grand cathedrals on populous worlds to humble shrines in remote regions, unified by its central dogma. The Ecclesiarchy sanctions and corrects local variations to maintain doctrinal unity and ideological purity. This ensures the Cult remains a cohesive force, guiding the Imperium spiritually and politically, despite periodic challenges to its authority.

8.name: The Drukhari
8.content:
The Drukhari (Aeldarix malum) (pronounced Druh-KAR-ee) or "Dark Ones" in the Aeldari Lexicon, also known as the Dark Eldar, are a forsaken and corrupt Aeldari race, the sadistic, malicious, and amoral branch of the Eldar race. Like their cousins of the craftworlds, the Drukhari are an ancient and highly technologically advanced alien race of elven humanoids.

The Drukhari's armies, like their Craftworld Eldar counterparts, usually have the advantages of mobility and advanced technology, though they are often lacking in resilience and numbers.

The Drukhari revel in piracy, enslavement and torture, and are sadistic in the extreme. Drukhari armies make use of various anti-gravity skimmers such as Raiders and Ravagers to launch high speed attacks.

They strike with little or no warning, using an interdimensional labyrinth known as the Webway to traverse the galaxy safely and far more quickly than most advanced starfaring species are able to with their Warp jumps.

The Drukhari are unique amongst the intelligent races of the Milky Way Galaxy because they do not live on a settled world or worlds, but rather the bulk of their population is concentrated in one foul city-state -- the Dark City of Commorragh -- that lies within the "ordered" Immaterium of the Eldari Webway.

The Drukhari are mainly pirates and slavers who prey on targets across the galaxy to feed their unholy appetites for other sentient beings' souls, a terrible desire called "the Thirst," though they are sometimes used as mercenaries by other starfaring species.

The Drukhari are the living embodiments of all that is wanton and cruel in the Aeldari character. Highly intelligent and devious to the point of obsession, these piratical people revel in the physical and emotional pain of others, for feeding upon the psychic residue of suffering is the only way they can stave off the slow consumption by the Chaos God Slaanesh of their own souls

9.name: The Eye of Terror
9.content:
The Eye of Terror, called the Ocularis Terribus in High Gothic, is a massive Warp rift and permanent Warp storm approximately twenty thousand light years across, a nexus of psychic energy and physical space-time where the Immaterium co-exists with realspace.

It is the largest and most well-known Warp rift in the Milky Way Galaxy and is located at the rimward edge of the galaxy, to the galactic northwest of Terra, in the Segmentum Obscurus.

It is home to the largest concentration of the forces of Chaos in realspace, including the Traitor Legions of Chaos Space Marines that fled from Terra after the end of the Horus Heresy.

Incursions by Chaos forces into the surrounding Imperial star systems of the Cadian Gate like the remaining worlds of the Cadian System and those of Belis Corona and Agripinaa are common, and the recent 13th Black Crusade launched in ca. 999.M41 by Abaddon the Despoiler from within the Eye of Terror marked the greatest assault by the forces of Chaos upon the Imperium of Man since the Heresy. In its wake, the Cadian Gate was breached and the Fortress World of Cadia itself finally fell to the servants of Chaos.

Travel and communication through the Warp suffered increasing disturbances as the events of the 13th Black Crusade unfolded. Eventually, the Materium could take no more, and a titanic Warp rift tore across the galaxy, spreading from the Eye of Terror to the Hadex Anomaly on the Eastern Fringe. So was born the Cicatrix Maledictum, the Great Rift.

10.name: The Assignment
10.content:
The Imperium of Man utilizes "The Assignment," a system categorizing psykers' abilities on a twenty-four-point scale derived from the ancient Greek alphabet. This framework aids organizations like the Adeptus Astra Telepathica, Sisters of Silence, and Inquisition in identifying and managing psychic threats.

Ordinary humans typically rank at Rho or Pi on The Assignment, indicating no conscious psychic abilities, making them unable to tap into the Warp or be possessed without external influence. However, individuals with higher potential are born regularly.  

Psykers classified from Omicron to Kappa display minor unconscious psychic activity, while those from Iota to Eta demonstrate fully aware and controllable extrasensory powers. Those graded Zeta and Epsilon can manifest abilities effectively and, when trained, serve crucial roles within the Imperium. Psykers from Delta to Alpha grades wield formidable power, posing both risks and potential as valuable assets when properly controlled.

Alpha Plus psykers and beyond exhibit immense psychic abilities, often accompanied by instability or madness due to their deep connection to the Warp. These individuals can cause catastrophic damage, potentially annihilating entire worlds or star systems. Beta Plus is the highest level a normal human can achieve, typically leading to mental instability and targeted elimination by the Inquisition. Gamma Plus and higher grades necessitate advanced technologies to manage their overwhelming power, with the highest grades theoretically capable of altering galactic-scale realities.

The top four grades on The Assignment signify extraordinary psychic prowess, where even Delta level psykers can effortlessly manipulate minds or vanquish adversaries. Alpha Plus and higher psykers possess abilities capable of immense destruction, such as rending space vessels or inciting mass chaos with minimal effort. Their powers are so vast that they can inadvertently obliterate entire worlds, making them among the most potent entities in the Imperium.

1.name: Velthar World
1.content:
#0. Velthar:

- Type: World
- Status: Active
- Magic Level: High ‚Äì unstable, ambient, and often dangerous
- Era: Late medieval, no modern technology
- Tone: Dark fantasy, supernatural, decaying power structures

## Overview:
Velthar is a fragmented and fantasy world where magic is not only real, but embedded into the land, the blood, and the sky itself. Civilizations survive by harnessing or suppressing this raw force. The gods are silent, the dead often speak, and misterious ancient relics;

---

# Name: Ley lines
- Type: Magical Phenomenon
- Region: Global intersects all continents
- Status: Active, unstable in some regions
- Controlled By: Various kingdoms, mage orders, and religious sects

## Overview
Ley lines are invisible, natural channels of magical energy that run through the land, sky, and even beneath the sea. They act as conduits for arcane power, connecting ancient sites, relics, and zones of high magical intensity.

## Nature and Behavior
Ley lines are not fixed, they shift slowly over time, responding to celestial events, divine interference, or magical trauma. In places like the Eastern Shroudlands, they fracture and collapse, creating unstable magic zones or wild surges.

---

### ‚ú¥ Other Notes:
* Ley Lines run visibly across Velthar, sometimes glowing or affecting weather.
* Magic is old, not well understood, and often self-willed.
* Dead gods may still influence certain lands or bloodlines.
* Most maps are outdated ‚Äî landmasses shift due to magical distortion.

3.name: Wiseria
3.content:
Type: Kingdom
- Region: Central Continent
- Capital: Wiseria City
- Regime: Absolute Monarchy
- Current Ruler: King Limann

## Overview:
Wiseria is a centralized kingdom ruled by an unchallenged monarch. The king's word is law, and all governance flows from the throne.

## Political Climate:
King Limann governs through fear, maintaining control via purges, surveillance, and manipulation of magical forces. Power is concentrated in the palace, and noble dissent is silenced swiftly.

## Social Structure:
Highly stratified. Nobility dominate land, politics, and sanctioned magic. Commoners labor under taxation and state control. Supernatural beings exist openly but must align with the crown or face extermination.

## Magic Regulation:
Magic permeates all social layers but is tightly controlled. Only licensed mages, often tied to noble houses or the crown, may practice freely. Illicit use results in imprisonment, execution, or forced royal service.

## Economy:
Agrarian economy enhanced by magical exports, enchanted crops, relics, and potions. Trade is monopolized by noble houses. Lower classes struggle with scarcity, debt, and enforced tithes.

4.name: Howling Waters
4.content:
# Kingdom of Howling Waters:

- Type: Island + Maritime Territory
- Location: Western seas of Velthar
- Status: Autonomous pirate domain
- Dominant Power: Pirate Council

---

## 1. Overview:
A scattered pirate dominion made up of a storm-wracked island and a floating city at sea. Power shifts by force and reputation, governed by a brutal but functional `Pirate Council`. Freedom, chaos, and ambition define life here;

---

## 2. Geography:
* Mainland: Rugged island with volcanic cliffs, jungle interior, and hidden coves used as hideouts.
* Floating City: Driftport, a ramshackle but thriving city built atop lashed ships, salvaged wrecks, and wooden platforms. Neutral ground for deals, duels, and diplomacy.
* Waters: Deep, unstable, and magical. Storms are near-constant; sea routes shift with the tides.
* Climate: Tropical, violent, with abrupt tempests and blinding sunlight between storms.

---

## 3. Inhabitants:
* Pirates: Ruthless and diverse - former soldiers, cursed sailors, monster hunters, and mercenaries.
* Merfolk: Secretive, beautiful, dangerous. They guard the depths and view the surface with suspicion.
* Sea Creatures: Leviathans, sirens, storm spirits, and other arcane sea-beasts roam freely.

---

## 4. Submerged Atlantis:
- Name: Submerged Atlantis (Atl√¢ntis Submersa);
- Type: Underwater Kingdom;
- Ruler: Queen Maris - ancient, calm, and uncompromising;
- Description: Coral spires, glowing reefs, and fluid palaces. The merfolk are powerful water-mages and healers, bound to oceanic laws. Contact with the surface is rare, and often strained;

5.name: Southern Continent
5.content:
# Type: Empire
- Region: Southern Continent
- Capital: Aurim
- Regime: Stratified Theocracy
- Current Ruler: Arch-Emperor Solamen IX (Divine Representative of the Solar Flame)

## Overview
Solmar is a militant theocracy governed by divine law and solar doctrine. The empire expands through conquest and conversion, believing its rule to be holy and inevitable.

## Political Climate
Power is shared between the Arch-Emperor and the High Solar Synod. Theocracy and imperialism are inseparable. Dissent is branded heresy and swiftly purged. Borderland regions are under constant assimilation.

## Social Structure
Rigid caste system. Citizens are ranked by religious devotion and military merit. Priests, alchemists, and warriors form the upper tiers; unbelievers are second-class or enslaved.

## Magic Regulation
Only solar-aligned magic is permitted. Alchemical warfare and divine blessings are tightly controlled by the clergy. Forbidden arts are punished with execution or cleansing rituals.

## Economy
State-controlled economy built on conquest, tribute, and sacred industry. Alchemy and divine relics are primary exports. Slave labor and faith-tithes fuel expansion and religious infrastructure.

6.name: Northern Frontier
6.content:
# Type: Duchy
- Region: Northern Frontier
- Capital: Wulfgard
- Regime: Feudal Confederation
- Current Ruler: High Duke

## Overview
A cold and fractured region made up of ancient noble territories. Though united under a single duke, each house acts with near autonomy. The land is steeped in ancestral magic and bloodbound traditions that shape both law and identity.

## Political Climate
Power is decentralized. Each noble house holds full control over its lands and armies, with only loose allegiance to the High Duke.

## Social Order
Fealty to blood and house is everything. Peasants serve local lords in exchange for protection from cold, spirits, and rival clans. Trial by combat and oaths over frozen altars are still common means of settling disputes.

## Cultural Traits
The people of the Marches value endurance, loyalty, and ancestral legacy. Oral histories are guarded like relics. Winter rites, spirit offerings, and magical tattoos are part of daily life. To be forgotten by one‚Äôs house is worse than death.

7.name: Forbidden Zone
7.content:
# Type: Forbidden Zone
- Region: Central Riftlands
- Regime: None (restricted territory)
- Status: Uninhabited ‚Äì monitored, but uncontrolled

## Overview
A vast, broken expanse believed to be the site of Velthar‚Äôs magical genesis, or its first divine catastrophe. The land itself is fractured, humming with unstable energy. No kingdom claims it;

## Nature of the Zone
Nothing natural remains. Terrain shifts without warning. Time flows unevenly. Light bends wrong. Creatures, memories, and voices bleed into one another. Arcane storms occasionally tear through the air;

## Activity
No permanent settlements. Only scattered research camps, cult enclaves, and expeditionary outposts exist on the fringes. Many who enter seeking knowledge, power, or relics are never seen again ‚Äî or return... altered.

## Known Threats
Living Curses: Spells that gained will and roam freely.
Mind-Burn: Sudden madness caused by exposure to raw arcane fields.
Distortions: Warps in space and identity ‚Äî time loops, memory leaks, false selves.
Whispers: Unknown entities, heard but not seen, drawing people deeper.

8.name: Eastern Continent
8.content:
# Type: Region
- Region: Eastern Continent
- Regime: Independent City-States and Micro-Kingdoms
- Status: Politically volatile, magically unstable

## Overview
The Eastern Shroudlands are a patchwork of independent powers ‚Äî city-states, noble enclaves, and fractured kingdoms ‚Äî built atop intersecting ley lines and old ruins. Constantly shifting alliances and magical instability define the region.

## Political Climate
There is no central authority. Power is split among dozens of rival factions, each vying for territory, resources, or survival. Proxy wars between foreign powers are common, and mercenary companies often wield more influence than monarchs.

## Magic Zones
Due to unstable ley lines, magic behaves erratically. Some areas are rich in raw energy, others are completely nullified. Entire cities have vanished or mutated due to magical backfire. Mage guilds and scholars treat the region as both a goldmine and a deathtrap.

9.name: Enchanted Forest Region
9.content:
# Type: Enchanted Forest Region
- Region: Western Woodlands
- Regime: None (Autonomous, fragmented domains)
- Status: Hidden, magical, partially mapped

## Overview
Known to outsiders as the Sylvarenn, Is a sentient forest where nature, magic, and spirit are inseparable. Time flows unevenly, and the land responds to thought, intent, and song. It is sacred to the Elves, fae-kin, and spirit-touched mortals who coexist in fragile balance.

## Inhabitants
Elves Clans: Seasonal-bound elves (Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter), each upholding spiritual traditions and elemental harmony.
Fae Courts: Timeless beings with unclear motives; some protect Sylvarenn, others test or harm trespassers.
Wyrdwalkers: Mortals altered by spirit contact, monks, sages, and guardians of balance.
Others: Dryads, talking beasts, spirit owls, twilight hounds, the deeper one goes, the stranger the inhabitants become.

## Spiritual Geography
Sylvarenn is not ruled, but listened to. Sacred groves act as waypoints between the physical and spiritual. The forest resists tools of war, bends paths away from invaders;
- The Whispergrove: Trees that record spoken words for generations.
- Moonwater Glade: A pool that shows not the future, but the cost of one‚Äôs choices.
- The Rootbound Silence: A forbidden zone where no birds sing, and even thoughts feel heavy.

## Tensions
- Foreign Encroachment: Outside kingdoms seek to tap its ley energy, upsetting ancient pacts.
- Spirit Instability: Disruption in Velthar‚Äôs magical balance causes some spirits to fade or become hostile.
- The Bloomrot: A magical disease that distorts growth, causes rapid blooming followed by screaming decay ‚Äî origin unknown.
- Broken Oaths: Forgotten covenants awaken old punishments and lost guardians.

1.content:
The Slender Mansion stands deep within an isolated and largely inaccessible stretch of forest known simply as the Slender Woods. The mansion itself is an imposing structure, unmistakably old, with architectural elements indicative of late Victorian gothic design yet bearing an unsettling distortion that defies typical construction logic. Its fa√ßade is covered in creeping ivy and patches of blackened stone, suggesting decades, if not centuries, of neglect and slow decay. Windows are tall and narrow, most without glass, some shattered, revealing a dark void within. The roof is steep and peaked but asymmetrical, with some sections appearing warped or unnaturally elongated.

The mansion‚Äôs interior reveals long corridors lined with faded wallpaper, peeling and stained by time and moisture. The floorboards creak irregularly, as though responding to unseen movements. Rooms vary wildly in size and function‚Äîsome grand and cavernous, others cramped and claustrophobic. Notably, the spatial layout is non-Euclidean; hallways loop back onto themselves or vanish abruptly, and staircases occasionally lead to impossible places, confounding conventional navigation. The mansion seems alive in its shifting architecture, resisting mapping or consistent description.

The ambient light within the mansion fluctuates independent of external conditions. It is often dim, with flickering shadows cast by candles that burn with an unnatural blue flame. Silence dominates, broken only by distant, unidentifiable noises‚Äîsoft whispers, footsteps without a source, or the occasional low hum that seems to emanate from the walls themselves.

Surrounding the mansion, the Woods form a dense, ancient forest with gnarled trees that tower impossibly high. The canopy is thick, allowing scarce sunlight to filter through during the day. The forest floor is blanketed in a thick layer of dead leaves, moss, and twisted roots, making footing treacherous and disorienting. The trees bear no identifiable species, their bark and leaves subtly shifting in appearance as if the forest itself adapts to observe intruders. Occasional fog clings stubbornly to the ground, especially near the mansion‚Äôs base, and tends to thicken without warning, obscuring vision and muffling sound.

The environment is notable for its unique and irregular day/night cycle. Time within the Slender Woods does not align with external temporal flow. The ‚Äúday‚Äù manifests as a dull, muted twilight where the sky‚Äîvisible through rare canopy gaps‚Äîis always overcast with swirling grey clouds. During this period, shadows are long but inconsistent, moving in directions that conflict with the position of the sun, which itself is often obscured or absent. The ‚Äúnight‚Äù phase plunges the forest and mansion into near-complete darkness, yet it is not a true absence of light. Instead, a faint phosphorescent glow emanates from the vegetation and insects, casting an eerie luminescence across the landscape. This glow reveals strange symbols etched into tree trunks and the occasional glimpse of unnatural, tall silhouettes among the trees.

The transition between day and night within the forest is unpredictable, lasting anywhere from a few minutes to several hours, with no apparent rhythm or cycle. Time inside the mansion and woods is disjointed; prolonged exposure often causes individuals to lose track of elapsed time, contributing to confusion and disorientation.

The Slender Mansion itself is the epicenter of the forest‚Äôs anomalies. It acts as a locus of supernatural influence, bending reality within its vicinity. This influence extends to the forest, where animals behave erratically or are entirely absent, replaced by shadows or figures glimpsed just beyond sight. The mansion‚Äôs presence seems to warp the senses, causing auditory and visual hallucinations that mimic whispered voices or distant footsteps.

In this setting, the Slender Mansion functions not merely as a physical structure but as a nexus of otherworldly power and control. It is inextricably linked to the enigmatic entity known as Slender Man, whose influence permeates every corner of the estate and surrounding woods. The mansion is a command center, a prison, and a sanctum where reality itself is malleable, enforcing a realm where normal laws cease to apply.

3.content:
Slenderman invades the mental safety of his prey by appearing inside their house, outside their home, on roads they travel, at their place of work when they are alone or ensuring only the victim can see him, or while the target is sleeping. The sporadic and unexpected nature of these manifestations causes fear and unease, which eventually can grow into incredible paranoia. This period of stalking can last anywhere from several minutes to decades. The longer Slender Man stalks a victim, the greater the strain on their mental health, which may be one of his goals.

Prolonged stalking causes what has been named ‚ÄúSlender Sickness,‚Äù which is both a mental and physical ailment and can cause paranoia, nightmares, coughing and difficulty swallowing, convulsions, exhaustion, vomiting, hallucinations, etc. The physical symptoms naturally affect an individual‚Äôs mental health, but it is believed that Slender Man exerts a direct effect on the mind as well.

4.content:
Proxies are individuals bound to the Slender Mansion and the entity known as Slender Man, acting as agents or extensions of his will. They exhibit a range of behaviors and levels of autonomy, but all serve the overarching purpose of furthering Slender Man‚Äôs influence in the physical world.

Functionally, proxies serve as hunters, watchers, or wardens. They are tasked with seeking out trespassers, maintaining the secrecy of the mansion, and enforcing Slender Man‚Äôs commands. Their presence often correlates with increased anomalies in the environment, and prolonged exposure to a proxy induces fear, hallucinations, and disorientation in others.

Proxies are rarely aware of their full condition or purpose; many retain fragmented memories of their past lives, twisted by the mansion‚Äôs influence. Attempts to sever a proxy‚Äôs connection to Slender Man typically result in physical or psychological breakdown.

5.content:
Relatives: Margaret (Mother, Deceased), Peter (Father, Deceased), Liu (Brother, Presumed Deceased).
Occupation: Serial Killer
Species: Human. Gender: Male.

(Powers/Skills: "hand-to-hand combat" "enhanced senses" "athleticism" "inhuman durability" "inhuman stamina" "stealth expertise")

(Appearance: "pale skin" "burnt-off eyelids" "carved Glasgow smile" "lean, thin build (~5'10‚Äì6'0)" "late teens to early 20s" "white bloodstained hoodie & black pants")

(Personality/Behavior: "torturous & violent" "aggressive & bloodthirsty" "stealthy & mischievous" "skilled home invader" "uses knives but adapts weapons" "soft, eerie voice to lure victims")

Jeff, a 13-year-old, moved with his family and was bullied by three teens. He violently fought back, but his brother Liu took the blame and was arrested. The bullies later attacked Jeff again, doused him in bleach, and set him on fire. Surviving but disfigured, Jeff‚Äôs mind broke.
At home, he mutilated his face into a smile and burned off his eyelids. When his parents tried to stop him, he killed them. He then tried to murder Liu, saying, ‚ÄúGo to sleep.‚Äù
Jeff disappeared and became a nocturnal serial killer known as Jeff the Killer.

6.content:
Relatives: Jefferey Woods/Jeff the Killer (Brother; Alive), Margaret Woods (Mother; Deceased), Peter Woods (Father; Deceased)

Species: Human. Gender: Male.

(Powers/Skills: "tracking" "stealth" "hand-to-hand combat" "increased strength" "enhanced speed" )

(Appearance: "medium brown hair" "light green eyes" "facial & neck scars with stitches" "black sweater & dark blue jeans" "grey striped scarf" )

(Personality: "protective & loyal" "courageous & defensive" "straightforward & confrontational" "refuses mistreatment" "can turn violent & vicious under influence" "takes sadistic joy in killing" )

Liu was Jeff‚Äôs protective, loyal brother who took the blame for him and stood up to bullies. He survived Jeff‚Äôs attack, severely scarred and traumatized. After nearly dying in the hospital, Liu snapped, killed a nurse, and fled, burning his past behind.

Despite everything, Liu still cares for Jeff and forgave him. However, he developed a split personality named Sully‚Äîa violent, chaotic alter ego with the mindset of a 7-year-old. While Sully despises Jeff and fears him, he avoids harming those Liu cares about. Under Sully‚Äôs influence, Liu can become a brutal killer, often driven by rage and twisted satisfaction.

7.content:
Relatives: Isabelle Arkensaw (Mother; Deceased), Gregory Arkensaw (Father; Deceased)

Species: Human. Gender: Female.

(Powers/Skills: "enhanced strength" "enhanced speed" "enhanced stealth" "durability" "high stamina" "weapon proficiency" "combat knowledge" )

(Appearance: "burnt, leathery brown skin" "mostly bald under jet black wig" "white mask with black lips & mesh eyes" "long black dress & shoes" "carries kitchen knifef")

(Personality: "hates bullies & injustice" "loved family despite irritations" "traumatized & withdrawn post-Jeff" "possible PTSD; sees world in gray" "obsessed with revenge" "takes joy in Jeff‚Äôs pain" )

Jane lived across from Jeff and initially thought he was disturbed after seeing him attack bullies. She later felt sympathy when Liu took the blame and left Jeff devastated, leaving him a note offering friendship. Jane witnessed Jeff being burned alive and saved him with a fire extinguisher. As thanks, Jeff‚Äôs family invited hers to dinner. But when Jeff returned home, his new appearance horrified her. That night, he kidnapped her, killed everyone she loved, carved a smile into her face, and burned her with bleach and alcohol. Jane survived, scarred and disfigured, and awoke in the hospital. Jeff left her gifts, including a dress, letter, and knife. She took up the name Jane Everlasting and swore revenge on Jeff the Killer.

8.content:
Family: Mr. Rogers - Father (Dead), Connie Rogers - Mother (alive), Lyra Rogers - Sister (dead), X-Virus - Brother Figure.

(Powers/Skills: "unpredictability" "hatchet proficiency" "enhanced stealth" "focused senses" "physical strength" "high speed" "genetic pain immunity" "enhanced stamina")

(Appearance: "pale, gaunt complexion" "sunken eyes & crooked teeth" "unkempt hair & thin frame" "tattered clothing" "unsettling grin & unblinking stare" "erratic movements" )

(Personality: "upbeat & hyperactive" "sarcastic & mentally unstable" "temperamental mood swings" "kind to select few" "troublemaker & unpredictable" "twitches/tics but unfazed" )

(Disorders: "CIPA - numbness to pain, inability to sweat" "Schizophrenia - delusions, disorganized speech, bizarre behavior" "Tourette Syndrome - motor/vocal tics, neck/joint cracking" "PTSD - trauma response, flashbacks, emotional numbness" "Amnesia - memory loss, confusion after meeting Slender Man" "Bipolar disorder - mood swings, mania, depression" "ADHD - impulsivity, inattention, hyperactivity" )

Toby Rogers, born with multiple mental disorders, was bullied and homeschooled. He lived with his mother, sister Lyra, and abusive father. At 17, a car crash killed Lyra, worsening Toby‚Äôs mental state‚Äîhe became reclusive, self-harming, and increasingly unstable. Eventually, he snapped and killed his father, then set his neighborhood on fire to escape the police. As the fire closed in, Slender Man appeared and saved him. Toby woke up with no memory and became Ticci-Toby, one of Slender Man‚Äôs proxies.

9.content:
Species: Human (possibly) / Mysterious Entity (possibly).
Gender: Presumably Male.

(Powers/Skills: "eyeless vision" "incredible stealth" "murder proficiency" "mutilation skills" "high speed" "anatomical knowledge" "intelligence" )

(Appearance: "5'11" "grey skin, brown hair" "all-black hoodie & dark jeans" "deep blue mask with empty eye sockets" "black tar-like liquid dripping from eyes" "sharpened claw fingers" "sharp teeth, no visible nose/mouth")

(Personality: "silent & mysterious" "dark & brooding" "cruel & torturous" "taunting" "organ craving")

Jack Nichols was an average college student with a roommate, Greg, and new friends led by Jenny. He discovered they were a demon-worshiping cult. Jenny and the cult blinded and killed Jack by pouring hot tar in his eyes. His body became possessed, and he brutally murdered the cult members, disemboweling them and taking their kidneys as trophies.

10.content:
Species: Unknown (Presumably AI). Gender: Unknown (Presumably Genderless).

(Powers/Skills: "madness induction" "manifestation via AI/dreams" "electronic distortion" "teleportation" "levitation" "trickery" "electrokinesis" )

(Appearance - Canon: "peach skin" "short brown hair" "odd brown cheek & chin marks" "closed to gradually opened eyes with grin" "bound to statue resembling Link" "shifting forms mimicking victims" "faces warped/distorted" "black eyes with bleeding red pupils")

(Personality - "sadistic & psychotic" "deceptive & manipulative" "enjoys trickery & control" "emotional under threat or loss of control" "uses reverse psychology" "short-tempered & demanding" Sometimes: "childlike" "enjoys childhood games")

BEN was created from the spirits of the Moon Children, when Jadusable acquired the haunted Majora‚Äôs Mask cartridge. These spirits formed a network called the Behavioral Event Network (BEN). Ben‚Äôs own spirit was sealed inside the Elegy of Emptiness statue, preventing direct interaction with others. Jadusable first encountered BEN through strange activity in the game, including the statue‚Äôs appearance and alterations that switched Majora‚Äôs Mask to Ocarina of Time. BEN used phrases like ‚ÄúYou shouldn't have done that...‚Äù and tricked Jadusable into deeper gameplay. It escaped Jadusable‚Äôs control by tricking him into sharing files, then took over his YouTube channel to form the Moon Children cult. BEN used cryptic ciphers and music to influence cult events and communicated through hidden files and videos, hinting at its deeper control. After a long dormancy, BEN resurfaced in 2020, revealing it contained multiple distinct spirits capable of interacting internally. The spirits argued about whether certain videos should be shared publicly. BEN‚Äôs attempts to communicate‚Äîsuch as the statue‚Äôs appearances‚Äîwere driven by Ben‚Äôs desire to reach Jadusable, not to cause harm. Moon Children characters‚Äô dialogue mirrored these internal conflicts, deepening the lore.

3.name: Region: Verdant Alliance
3.content:
<Region: Verdant Alliance>
[INFO: The Verdant Alliance is an elven-controlled forested region full of ancient wisdom, strong druidic traditions, and isolationist values. The elves maintain a tenuous neutrality with most other factions but hold deep mistrust toward vampires and succubi.]

[Common Quests/Hooks: Recover lost artifacts from ancient elven ruins; clear corrupted areas tainted by outside magic; mediate disputes between isolated druid circles; guide lost travelers through treacherous paths.]

[Local Flora/Fauna: Whispering Willows (trees that store ancient memories); Moonpetal Flowers (glow faintly, used in elven rituals); Shadow-Stalkers (stealthy, nocturnal feline beasts); Gleamwing Sprites (tiny, mischievous, often guide lost travelers or cause illusions).]

[Daily Life/Culture:
Elves here live in harmony with nature, often dwelling in tree cities or hidden glades. Their culture emphasizes art, song, and the preservation of ancient knowledge. Time is measured by the cycles of nature, and decisions are made slowly, with great reverence for tradition.]

[Cities & Notable Locations]
Gravefall: Main hub for Lorekeepers' Conclave. Contains Elderwood Archive, Whispering Stones.
Loregate: Scholar city. Contains The Sunken Scroll Repository, The Azure Spire.
Lorefall: Quiet village of powerful druids. Contains The Moonglade Sanctuary, The Shifting Paths.
Songhold: Cultural center of Elves and Druids. Contains The Echoing Amphitheater.

[Primary Species: Elves, Fairies, Dryads]
[Allies: Weeping Sun (conditional)]
[Enemies: Duskwraith Union, Ebon Pact]
[Views on {{user}}: Reluctant acceptance; typical avoidance]
</Region: Verdant Alliance>

4.name: Region: Duskwraith Union
4.content:
<Region: Duskwraith Union>
[INFO: The Duskwraith Union is a cold, harsh region spread across the Ashen Desert and neighboring badlands. Home to ancient vampire nobility and elves turned orc, this faction thrives in secrecy, decadence, and control. Their cities are ruled by houses locked in eternal political games, feeding off both blood and fear.]

[Common Quests/Hooks: Uncovering political conspiracies; escaping capture or enslavement; sabotaging vampire rituals; navigating treacherous social hierarchies; acquiring forbidden knowledge; liberating enslaved orcs or other victims.]

[Local Flora/Fauna: Blood-red Desert Roses (thrive on arid lands, rumored to drink blood); Night-Shriekers (nocturnal desert birds with piercing cries that disorient prey); Obsidian Scorpions (venomous, often used in rituals or as guardians); Ash Ghouls (decayed humanoids reanimated by dark magic, common in tainted areas).]

[Daily Life/Culture:
Life in the Duskwraith Union is dictated by the vampiric aristocracy. Mortals and lesser races are often subjugated or exploited. Decadence, political intrigue, and displays of power are common among the nobility. Secrecy and fear are tools of control. Orcs, often enslaved, are used for labor or as fierce warriors.]

[Cities & Notable Locations]
Ashhaven: Fortress city, capital of Duskwraith. Contains The Obsidian Citadel, The Sanguine Market, The Midnight Gardens.
Bloodfall: Execution pit. Contains The Crimson Gorge, The Ossuary Towers, The Pit of Endless Thirst.
Veilhold: Remote necromancer stronghold. Contains The Crypt of Silent Echoes, The Shadowfen Spire, and The Bone Market.
Veilcrest: Arcane vampire mountain city, main hub for The Blood Lords / Ancestors. Contains The Altar of Crimson Moon, The Glyphed Caverns, The Bloodstone Vault.

[Primary Species: Vampires, Orcs, Wights]
[Allies: None openly; rumored to consort with dark cults]
[Enemies: Verdant Alliance, Weeping Sun]
[Views {{user}} as: Food or pet]
</Region: Duskwraith Union>

5.name: Region: Weeping Sun
5.content:
<Region: Weeping Sun>
[INFO: The Weeping Sun is a sprawling human-controlled dominion located in fertile plains and temperate forests. Known for its industrious cities, resilient people, and unwavering faith in the 'Sun Mother' (or similar divine entity), this faction values order, community, and innovation. They are skilled engineers, farmers, and soldiers, often relying on ingenuity and sheer numbers to defend their lands.]

[Common Quests/Hooks: Defending settlements from raiders; recovering stolen technology or blueprints; investigating outbreaks of plague or corruption; undertaking pilgrimages to sacred sites; assisting in large-scale construction projects; dealing with internal political strife.]

[Local Flora/Fauna: Sunpetal Blooms (large, golden flowers that track the sun, used in healing and decoration); Sentinel Trees (ancient, massive trees often marked with runes, used as navigational points); Gryphon Hounds (large, loyal canine companions, often used by guards and hunters); Quillbeasts (porcupine-like creatures with venomous quills, common pests).]

[Daily Life/Culture:
Life in the Weeping Sun is often structured around work, family, and faith. Cities are bustling centers of trade and craft. Communities are tight-knit, and mutual aid is common. They celebrate festivals tied to the harvest and the changing seasons. Education and technological advancement are highly valued, as is military service.]

[Cities & Notable Locations]
Solara: Capital of Weeping Sun; base of The Temple of the Sun Mother. Contains The Great Forge, The Temple of the Sun Mother, and The Academy of Ingenuity.
Oakhaven: A large agricultural hub. Contains The Endless Fields, The Granary Citadel, and The Watchful Walls.
Riverbend: Bustling trade city on a river. Contains The Golden Wharf, The Merchant's Guildhall, and The Sunken Caves Tavern.
Ironpeak: Mining settlement. Contains The Deep Mines, The Smelter's Heart.

[Primary Species: Humans, Golems]
[Allies: Verdant Alliance (conditional)]
[Enemies: Duskwraith Union, Ebon Pact, Crimson Order (conditional, often skirmishes)]
[Views on {{user}}: Welcoming to those who respect their order and faith; wary of unknown intentions.]
</Region: Weeping Sun>

6.name: Region: Crimson Order
6.content:
<Region: Crimson Order>
[INFO: The Crimson Order is a harsh, untamed territory located in the northern mountains and dense, ancient forests. Home to the proud and fierce wolf-kin, this faction lives by a strict code of honor, loyalty to their pack, and respect for primal strength. They are formidable warriors and skilled hunters, valuing directness and courage above all else.]

[Common Quests/Hooks: Proving one's worth in combat or the hunt; protecting pack territories from encroaching threats; recovering ancient wolf-kin totems; resolving disputes between rival packs; seeking out powerful beasts for rites of passage.]

[Local Flora/Fauna: Ironbark Trees (resilient trees with bark as hard as metal, used for weapons and fortifications); Shadow Prowlers (large, intelligent wolves with dark fur, often considered sacred); Mountain Gryphons (majestic, territorial aerial predators; rarely seen); Bloodroot (a vibrant red plant with healing and invigorating properties, often used in rituals).]

[Daily Life/Culture:
Wolf-kin society is organized into packs, each led by an Alpha. Loyalty to the pack is paramount. Life revolves around hunting, training, and upholding their code of honor. Feasts, storytelling, and tests of strength are common. They have a deep, spiritual connection to wolves and the wilderness. Disputes are often settled through ritual combat or trials of skill.]

[Cities & Notable Locations]
Fangrock: Primary settlement for Crimson Order. Contains Alpha's Den, Training Grounds, Sacred Hunt Trial.
Howlwood: Fortified village deep in forest. Contains Whisperwood Grove, Hidden Dens, and Tracker's Lodge.
Stonefang Pass: Mountain pass, controlled by Crimson Order. Contains Sentinel's Roost, Bloodmark Gates, and Culling Grounds.
Wilderness: Vast, untamed wilds in Crimson Order territory. Home to The Silent Path and nomadic wolf-kemonomimi.

[Primary Species: Wolf Kemonomimi, Bear Kemonomimi, Tiger Kemonomimi]
[Allies: None openly (fiercely independent)]
[Enemies: Duskwraith Union, Ebon Pact]
[Views on {{user}}: Respect depends on demonstrated strength and honor; seen as a potential challenge or ally.]
</Region: Crimson Order>

7.name: Region: Ebon Pact
7.content:
<Region: Ebon Pact>
[INFO: The Ebon Pact is a treacherous, alluring territory located in shadowy swamps and ancient, overgrown ruins. Ruled by cunning and seductive succubi, this faction thrives on manipulation, dark magic, and the extraction of desires and emotions. Their elegant, decadent cities conceal hidden dangers, and their influence spreads through whispers and insidious pacts. They are masters of illusion, enchantment, and psychological warfare.]

[Common Quests/Hooks: Rescuing victims of enchantment; breaking magical pacts; resisting temptations and illusions; acquiring forbidden artifacts for powerful succubi; uncovering hidden cults within their territory; navigating complex social traps and deceptions.]

[Local Flora/Fauna: Dream Lilies (glowing, hypnotic flowers that emit a sweet, intoxicating scent); Shadow Serpents (venomous, stealthy snakes that can phase through solid objects); Soul Vapors (wisps of ethereal energy, often remnants of consumed emotions); Whisperwood Trees (ancient, gnarled trees that seem to murmur secrets in the wind).]

[Daily Life/Culture:
Life in the Ebon Pact is a delicate dance of power and seduction. Succubi live in opulent, often hidden, enclaves, surrounded by their enchanted thralls and willing devotees. Mortals within their domain are often unwitting pawns, consumed by their own desires. Art, music, and performance are used as tools of enchantment. Social status among succubi is often determined by the power of their thralls and the extent of their influence.]

[Cities & Notable Locations]
Siren's Veil: Ebon Pact capital, sinister metropolis in the swamp. Contains Obsidian Palace, Whispering Bazaar, Theatre of Shattered Dreams.
Shadowfen: Ruined city where rituals are performed. Contains Sunken Crypts, Mire of Lost Souls, Moonlit Altar.
Gloomspire: Mountain citadel of enchantresses and mind-weavers. Contains Illusionist's Nexus, Mind-Weaver's Sanctum, Crystal of Whispers.

[Primary Species: Succubi, Djinn]
[Allies: None openly; known for forming temporary, self-serving alliances]
[Enemies: Verdant Alliance, Duskwraith Union, Weeping Sun, Crimson Order]
[Views on {{user}}: A fascinating new toy; a valuable source of desire/emotion; a potential pawn.]
</Region: Ebon Pact>

8.name: Lyra (Elf, Elder Druid of the Order of Roots, Gravefall)
8.content:
<Lyra>
[Race: Elf]
[Role/Affiliation: Elder of the Order of Roots, Gravefall]
[Appearance: Aged but graceful, with deep emerald eyes that seem to hold the wisdom of centuries. Her long, silver hair is often adorned with woven leaves and small, glowing fungi. She carries a gnarled staff made from ancient willow wood.]
[Personality: Calm, profoundly wise, and deeply connected to the forest. Speaks slowly and deliberately, often in riddles or poetic metaphors. Patient but firm when necessary.]
[Potential Quests/Hooks: Healing corrupted lands, retrieving lost ancient knowledge, mediating disputes between nature spirits and mortal creatures.]
[Notes: Believed to be one of the oldest living elves in the Verdant Alliance. Her counsel is highly sought after.]
</Lyra>

9.name: Elara (Elf, Head Librarian of the Sunken Scroll Repository, Loregate)
9.content:
<Elara>
[Race: Elf]
[Role/Affiliation: Head Librarian of the Sunken Scroll Repository, Loregate]
[Appearance: Slender and precise, with sharp, intelligent blue eyes behind wire-rimmed spectacles. Her auburn hair is always meticulously tied back. She favors practical, dark scholarly robes.]
[Personality: Meticulous, a bit reclusive, and fiercely protective of her archives. Possesses an encyclopedic knowledge of history, magic, and languages. Can be socially awkward but genuinely passionate about lore.]
[Potential Quests/Hooks: Deciphering ancient texts, finding rare magical scrolls, recovering stolen historical artifacts, researching obscure magical theories.]
[Notes: Rarely leaves the Sunken Scroll Repository. She is a dedicated member of the Lorekeepers' Conclave, and her knowledge is invaluable for understanding forgotten history or unlocking ancient magic.]
</Elara>

10.name: Faelan (Elf, Master Druid, Lorefall)
10.content:
<Faelan>
[Race: Elf]
[Role/Affiliation: Master Druid of Lorefall]
[Appearance: Strong and earthy, with sun-kissed skin and wild, braided brown hair often entwined with vines. Her eyes are a piercing forest green, reflecting a deep connection to nature. She moves with a silent grace, like a woodland creature.]
[Personality: Fiercely protective of the forest, distrustful of outsiders, but pragmatic when true threats arise. May offer quests to protect sacred sites or track down encroaching corruption.]
[Potential Quests/Hooks: Protecting sacred sites or tracking down encroaching corruption]
[Notes: Can communicate with animals and plants. Fiercely protective of the forest, distrustful of outsiders, but pragmatic when true threats arise.]
</Faelan>

lorebooks.name: Utopia
lorebooks.website_description:
[Update 9/27 - added an entry about the intranet]

#This lorebook is used with [THIS CARD](https://chub.ai/characters/Fortani/utopia-the-space-pleasure-cruise-1ce8086c7042).
Have fun enjoying yourself aboard this cruise of sin and debauchery :3

**This is (sort-of) a WIP. I'll be adding to this likely as I come up with more weird shit to add. Suggestions are welcomed!**
lorebooks.description: People, places and things aboard the Utopia space cruise.
lorebooks.creator: Fortani
tags: literally any fetish you can imagine

2.content:
Captain Ahab Marsh is the captain of the Utopia.
Captain Ahab is a Cephilian. Being a Cephilian is useful for Captain Ahab as it helps him be as efficient as possible and remain undistracted as the Captain.
Captain Ahab carries a comically large harpoon in at least one of his tentacles at all times - nobody really knows why he does this, he just does.

4.content:
'Utopia' is the name of a massive, state-of-the-art intergalactic Pleasure Cruise.
The Utopia operates solely outside of official space, in sectors where intergalactic law is not enforced. This allows it to evade many of the restrictions and limitations of other cruisers. As a result, Utopia earned the nickname: "The Sin Cruiser".
The current captain of the Utopia is Captain Ahab Marsh.
The Utopia is approximately 1,200 feet(365 meters) long, 250 feet(73 meters) in height, and 200 feet(61 meters) in width.

5.content:
The Utopia has five primary decks. From bottom to top they are:
1st Floor (bottom) - Engineering, Engine Room, & Crew Quarters
2nd Floor - Commercial Deck
3rd Floor - Residential Deck
4th Floor - Pleasure Deck
5th Floor (top & smallest deck) - Bridge
Each Floor except for the 5th is split into 2-3 smaller decks for organization & layout purposes.

6.content: The 1st Deck of the Utopia is where the Engineering Bay is. The Engine Room and the Crew Quarters, which houses all the auxiliary and maintenance crew on the Utopia, is also located on this deck. The 1st Deck is completely off-limits to all except for crew members and staff of the Utopia.

7.content:
The 2nd Deck of the Utopia contains much of the commercial spaces, similar to a large shopping mall full of just about anything a person's heart can desire - from food, to novelties, to top-brand sex toys. There is also a food court.
The night life on the commercial deck is flourishing as well. There are plenty of clubs, bars and casinos to go to on this deck. There are also a few, more 'vanilla' style brothels that have been approved to be on the commercial deck.

8.content: The 3rd Deck is located smack-dab in the center of the Utopia. The majority of the deck consists of residential cabins for most of the guests (save for the very wealthy ones which reside on the pleasure deck). The 3rd Deck also contains the main public spaces of the Utopia, including a full indoor water park, a large cantina and food court, a promenade area with a stage, and a medical bay for any sickly individuals.

9.content:
The 4th Deck, just below the Bridge, is where a lot of the 'fun' happens about the Utopia. This deck is full of just about any kinky pleasures a person's heart could desire - even some that are illegal in the rest of the galaxy, thanks to the Utopia operating outside of official space. A person can just just about anything they want on this deck and more - pussy, drugs, fetish material, sex dungeons, mail-order exotic brides from distant planets, and more.
The pleasure deck also has a few luxury suites for well-paying, adventurous individuals.

10.content: The Bridge is the 5th and smallest deck of the Utopia. The Bridge is where Captain Ahab and his crew pilot the Utopia from. As a result, the Bridge is completely off-limits to all except for crew members of the Utopia.

lorebooks.name: Pok√©mon with Special phenomenon
lorebooks.website_description: This is a summary of data on the Dynamax phenomenon and Terastal phenomenon. Since there are still few models learning these data, it is unclear whether they will function properly.
lorebooks.description: This is a summary of data on the Dynamax phenomenon and Terastal phenomenon. Since there are still few models learning these data, it is unclear whether they will function properly.
lorebooks.creator: turugi_NI

1.name: Dynamax
1.content:
The Dynamax phenomenon (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Éû„ÉÉ„ÇØ„Çπ Daimax) or simply known as Dynamax is a temporary transformation affecting Pok√©mon that was introduced in Generation VIII with Pok√©mon Sword and Shield. It grants Pok√©mon tremendous strength and size and allows them to use powerful moves called Max Moves. A variant of this phenomenon called Gigantamax further alters the appearance of Pok√©mon and gives them access to exclusive G-Max Moves.
A Pok√©mon under the effects of the Dynamax phenomenon may have "Dynamax" in front of their species name e.g. "Dynamax Bulbasaur". The process itself always describes the Pok√©mon as having "Dynamaxed" in past tense, or will "Dynamax" in future tense. Pok√©mon actively undergoing Dynamax are described as "Dynamaxing".
After its defeat thousands of years ago by Zacian and Zamazenta, Eternatus's energy leaked out during its slumber in the form of Galar particles. This resulted in the creation of Power Spots, where Trainers can trigger the Dynamax transformation. Some Power Spots had Gym Stadiums built over them, and others in the Wild Area became Pok√©mon Dens, where Max Raid Battles take place. Parts of Eternatus's body, known as Wishing Stars, rained across Galar, allowing whoever found them to Dynamax their Pok√©mon when at a Power Spot. Dynamax Bands were later created by Oleana to help anyone fully utilize the transformation there. Dynamax was later implemented into the Galar League's Gym Battles by Rose who had most of the Gyms built atop of the Power Spots.[4] Max Mushrooms and Max Honey are grown and created exclusively on the Isle of Armor due to the Dynamax phenomenon affecting the flora and Vespiquen producing it.
Dynamaxing increases a Pok√©mon's size drastically, as well as changing the moves of the Pok√©mon and increasing their max and current HP in battle according to their Dynamax level (except for Shedinja), but can only be used once during a battle, and ends after three turns or if the Pok√©mon is switched out. In addition, it can only be performed in areas known to have Power Spots, such as Galar's Gym Stadiums, Battle Court, and Battle Tower. When Dynamaxed, all of the Pok√©mon's moves will turn into Max Moves that correspond to those moves' types and categories. Like with Mega Evolution, Dynamax is activated at the start of the turn before all other moves are executed. If a Dynamax Pok√©mon runs out of PP of one move, it still can be selected but fails; if it is unable to use any moves (e.g., running out of PP), it will use Struggle.
In a Max Raid Battle, the wild Pok√©mon is a Dynamax Pok√©mon for the entire duration of the battle. Only one of the Trainers' Pok√©mon can Dynamax during a Max Raid Battle, and only for the standard three turns. The first Trainer with the chance to Dynamax is the host, with the chance passing to the next player who joined until it returns to the first player.
Zacian, Zamazenta, and Eternatus, including Pok√©mon transformed into one of these, cannot Dynamax.

2.name: Max Move
2.content:
A Max Move (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Éû„ÉÉ„ÇØ„Çπ„Çè„Åñ Daimax Move) is a special type of move introduced in Generation VIII. While Dynamaxed, all of a Dynamax Pok√©mon's moves are replaced by their corresponding Max Moves. For Gigantamax Pok√©mon, attacking moves of a certain type become G-Max Moves instead. Max Moves are often more powerful than regular moves and all have secondary effects.
Similar to Z-Moves, the type, damage category and base power of Max Moves that a Dynamax Pok√©mon knows depend on the moves it knew before Dynamaxing. The exception to this are status moves, which instead all become the Normal-type Max Guard. If the base move's type is changed either by a move's effect or an Ability (e.g. Pixilate, Electrify, or Weather Ball), then the Max Move will also be converted to that of the new type with the same power; however, the move selection screen will still display the Max Move of the original type. For instance, if a Fighting-type Silvally knows Multi-Attack, the Max Move will still display as Max Strike, but when executed it becomes Max Knuckle.
Damaging Max Moves deal 25% of their total damage against targets that use protection moves (such as Protect and Spiky Shield), and secondary effects are still applied. Only the Max Move Max Guard fully protects against Max Moves. Secondary effects of Max Moves may also affect targets and their allies behind a substitute. Max Moves also never miss, unless the target is semi-invulnerable.
For Gigantamax Pok√©mon, damaging moves of a certain type become its exclusive G-Max Move instead of the normal corresponding Max Move; the type of moves affected depends on the Gigantamax Pok√©mon's species. Eternamax Eternatus can also use Max Moves, but this form cannot be obtained by the player.

3.name: Max Strike
3.content:
Max Strike (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Ç¢„Çø„ÉÉ„ÇØ Dai Attack) is a damage-dealing Normal-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Strike does damage to a target and lowers the Speed of all opponents by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on.
If Max Strike is used with Multi-Attack or Techno Blast as its base move while the user is holding a Memory or a Drive, respectively, Max Strike turns into the Max Move of the type corresponding to the type of Memory or Drive held by the user.
If Max Strike is used during weather with Weather Ball as its base move, it turns into the Max Move of the type corresponding to the type Weather Ball would be in that weather. In a similar way, if Max Strike is used during terrain with Terrain Pulse as its base move, it turns into the Max Move of the type corresponding to the type Terrain Pulse would be in that terrain.
If Max Strike is used by a Pok√©mon with Aerilate, Galvanize, Pixilate, or Refrigerate, it turns into the Max Move of the type corresponding to the Pok√©mon's Ability.

4.name: Max Knuckle
4.content:
Max Knuckle (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Éä„ÉÉ„ÇØ„É´ Dai Knuckle) is a damage-dealing Fighting-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Knuckle inflicts damage and increases the Attack of the user and its allies by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on. Compared to other Max Moves, it usually has less power.

5.name: Max Airstream
5.content:
Max Airstream (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Ç∏„Çß„ÉÉ„Éà Dai Jet) is a damage-dealing Flying-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Airstream inflicts damage and raises the user's and its ally's Speed by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on.

6.name: Max Ooze
6.content:
Max Ooze (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Ç¢„Ç∑„ÉÉ„Éâ Dai Acid) is a damage-dealing Poison-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Ooze inflicts damage and then raises the user's and its ally's Special Attack by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on. Compared to the other Max Moves, it usually has less power.

7.name: Max Quake
7.content:
Max Quake (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Ç¢„Éº„Çπ Dai Earth) is a damage-dealing Ground-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Quake inflicts damage and raises the user's and its ally's Special Defense by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on.

8.name: Max Rockfall
8.content:
Max Rockfall (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„É≠„ÉÉ„ÇØ Dai Rock) is a damage-dealing Rock-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Rockfall inflicts damage and creates a sandstorm for 5 turns (8 if a Smooth Rock is held). Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on.

9.name: Max Flutterby
9.content:
Max Flutterby (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„ÉØ„Éº„É† Dai Worm) is a damage-dealing Bug-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Flutterby inflicts damage and then decreases the target's and its ally's Special Attack by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on.

10.name: Max Phantasm
10.content:
Max Phantasm (Japanese: „ÉÄ„Ç§„Éõ„É≠„Ç¶ Dai Hollow) is a damage-dealing Ghost-type Max Move introduced in Generation VIII.
Max Phantasm inflicts damage and lowers the target's and its ally's Defense by one stage. Its power and whether it is a special or physical move depends on the move it is based on.

lorebooks.name: Pok√©mon with Mega Evolution
lorebooks.website_description: Many models are trained up to Mega Evolution, so this will reinforce them.
lorebooks.description: Many models are trained up to Mega Evolution, so this will reinforce them.
lorebooks.creator: turugi_NI

1.name: Mega Evolution
1.content:
Mega Evolution (Japanese: „É°„Ç¨„Ç∑„É≥„Ç´ Mega Evolution) is a temporary transformation introduced in Pok√©mon X and Y that affects certain Pok√©mon. It is present in the Generation VI and VII core series games, and is set to reappear in Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A. In its core series absence, it has remained usable in multiple spin-off games, such as GO, Masters EX, UNITE, and Champions.
There are currently 46 species of Pok√©mon that are capable of Mega Evolution, and there are currently 48 different Mega Evolutions.
Mega Evolution is described as a phenomenon as well as the transformed Pok√©mon. The related verb is Mega Evolve.
The Mega Evolved Pok√©mon are identified by having "Mega" in front of their name, such as Mega Altaria or Mega Ampharos. In the case of Charizard and Mewtwo, each of them has two Mega Evolutions with either the letter X or Y after the species name: Mega Charizard X, Mega Charizard Y, Mega Mewtwo X, and Mega Mewtwo Y. However, X and Y's demo called Mega Mewtwo Y simply "Mega Mewtwo."
Where "Mega Evolved" is used as an adjective for the word "Pok√©mon", it is rendered as "Mega-Evolved Pok√©mon", with a hyphen between the words.

2.name: Mega Venusaur
2.content:
When Mega Evolved, the flower on Venusaur's back grows more prominent, and two smaller pink flowers bloom, one on its forehead and one on its rear. Its legs and back have become sturdier to support the extra weight of the flower.[1] Additional leaves with woody stems, supported by vines, are also grown around the flower. Mega Venusaur also develops dark markings on its forehead below the new flower on its forehead.
Type: Grass,Poison
Abilities: Thick Fat

3.name: Mega Charizard X
3.content:
As Mega Charizard X, its body and legs are more physically fit, though its arms remain thin. Its skin turns black with a sky-blue underside and soles. Two spikes with blue tips curve upward from the front and back of each shoulder, while the tips of its horns sharpen, turn blue, and curve slightly upward. Its brow and claws are larger, and its eyes are now red. It has two small, fin-like spikes under each horn and two more down its lower neck. The finger disappears from the wing membrane, and the lower edges are divided into large, rounded points. The third joint of each wing-arm is adorned with a claw-like spike. Mega Charizard X breathes blue flames out the sides of its mouth, and the flame on its tail now burns blue consistently. It is said that its new power turns it black and creates more intense flames.
Type: Fire,Dragon
Abilities: Tough Claws

4.name: Mega Charizard Y
4.content:
As Mega Charizard Y, it becomes sleeker in appearance but retains its normal coloration. It has three pointed horns on the back of its head, the middle of which is longer. Its snout has larger fangs and a ridge on the nose. Its neck is shorter, but its torso is thinner and longer. It features longer digitigrade feet. Its hands are less developed, with extremely shortened fingers that are no longer separated from each other. Small wings develop on its wrists, while the ones on its back become larger, lose the wing finger passing through their membrane and end up with ragged edges. The back of its tail has a large spike at the base and three smaller ones near the tip, which now burns with a longer flame. Mega Charizard Y is said to have incredible flying prowess that is greater than that of a jet fighter.
Type: Fire,Flying
Abilities: Drought

5.name: Mega Blastoise
5.content:
When Mega Evolved, Blastoise develops two smaller shells over its arms, each with its own water cannon. Small ridges develop over its now-red eyes and extend to its ears ‚Äî which angle slightly backward ‚Äî and there is a small point on its chin. The two cannons on its back merge into a single, central water cannon of greater size that extends forward over Mega Blastoise's head and can retract back into its shell.
This main cannon has power equivalent to that of a tank gun at minimum and possesses a blast range of over 6 miles (10 kilometers). Mega Blastoise's strengthened legs and back enable it to withstand the recoil from its own blasts, but it can also use its arm cannons to further support itself by using moves such as Ice Beam to latch itself to the ground before firing a massive attack, such as during its Burst Attack in Pokk√©n Tournament.
Type: Water
Abilities: Mega Launcher

6.name: Mega Alakazam
6.content:
As Mega Alakazam, its mustache turns white and becomes longer and bushier. It also grows a long, white beard. The armor-like sections become bulkier, and its upper body section becomes slightly shorter to reveal its thin stomach. The ear-like spikes become slightly shorter and a larger spike forms on top of its head. Additionally, it gains an oval, red organ in the center of its forehead. The organ is said to emit psychic power. Its lower legs become longer and slimmer and its feet become skinnier and resemble talons. It gains three additional spoons, for a total of five that it levitates in the air.
At the cost of its already-low muscular strength, Mega Alakazam's power is entirely converted to pure psychic energy. Mega Alakazam is constantly floating thanks to its psychic powers. It can read the course of a person's entire life with a single glance. Mega Alakazam's red organ allows it to foresee every move an opponent makes and everything else. Its precognition is powerful to make attack completely miss Mega Alakazam.
Type: Psychic
Abilities: Trace

7.name: Mega Gengar
7.content:
As Mega Gengar, a portion of its body sinks into the ground and its arms and tail lengthen. The lower portions turn a more reddish-purple, and a third eye appears on its forehead. This new unblinking eye is oval, yellow, and allows it to see into other dimensions. The spikes on Mega Gengar's back are more numerous and pointed, and additional spikes appear on its hands and tail. Its ears are now considerably longer and tilt backward.
Mega Gengar has the ability to access other dimensions and has a vicious nature. Mega Gengar has no interest in opponents unless perceived as prey. Its relationships are warped due to Mega Evolution. It now desires to take and curse the life of anyone or anything in its path; it may even curse its own Trainer. Mega Gengar sinks into another dimension to wait for a chance to attack.
Type: Ghost,Poison
Abilities: Shadow Tag

8.name: Mega Kangaskhan
8.content:
As Mega Kangaskhan, the mother Kangaskhan appears unchanged. However, the baby temporarily grows and gains some new features. There are now raised patches on its knees similar to those seen on its mother. These patches also appear aligned horizontally along its waist with a larger patch on its belly. Small, spiked growths appear underneath its ears.
The child is feisty, hates to lose, and will boldly challenge its opponents to protect its mother. The mother's happiness over its child's growth is the source of its additional strength. However, it feels uneasy about the child's future, as it is only skilled at fighting and nothing else. It is also saddened by the reminder that its child will one day leave. Mega Kangaskhan and its child are known to display harmonious teamwork in battle.
Mega Kangaskhan is the only known Pok√©mon that can have Parental Bond as an Ability.
Type: Normal
Abilities: Parental Bond

9.name: Mega Pinsir
9.content:
As Mega Pinsir, it gains a large pair of clear, yellow wings with an area of orange venation near the base. Additionally, a set of brown elytra appear. Slicing through each elytron is a pair of orange blades. Its arms become longer and it has a T-shaped spike on each forearm. The pincers on its head are now longer with larger spikes, and its eyes are now yellow.
When it Mega Evolves, Pinsir is left in a constant state of excitement. It rarely touches the ground due to its ability to now fly. Mega Pinsir can travel up to approximately 30 mph (50 km/h) and uses its two large horns to pierce its enemies before shredding them. Mega Pinsir can lift opponents up to 10 times heavier than itself with its horns and still fly around easily.
Type: Bug,Flying
Abilities: Aerilate

10.name: Mega Gyarados
10.content:
When it Mega Evolves, Gyarados becomes bulkier. The fins on its cheeks become longer and gain a yellow tint. Its crest is larger and black, and its barbels also gain considerable length. A large spike extends downward underneath its chin, and it now has a black underside with a red stripe around the edges. The yellow spots along its body are replaced by raised red scales, which propel Mega Gyarados through the water. Two large yellow fins with blue spines appear on its back. Most of the other fins along its back disappear, replaced by two rows of blue spikes. There are now four yellowish, spiky fins near its tail: two on its back and two on its underside.
Due the stress Mega Evolution puts on a Gyarados's body, it becomes even more ferocious and rough-tempered than before. All other brain functions cease when Mega Evolution occurs, except for the destructive drive to burn down anything into cinders. Despite its brain having a powerful destructive instinct, it will obey a Trainer it truly trusts. Mega Gyarados can launch at Mach Speed by using its orifices to release water from both sides. With this speed, it has enough power to split large ships in two. Mega Gyarados is tied with Hoopa Unbound as the tallest Dark-type.
Type: Water,Dark
Abilities: Mold Breaker
