1.content:
Neverness to Everness (NTE; Chinese: ÂºÇÁéØ) is an open-world action RPG developed by Hotta Studio and published by Perfect World Games. Set in the retro futuristic city of Hethereau, with supernatural urban setting, anime aesthetics, and GTA-inspired freedom.
Hethereau: a bustling metropolis teeming with life and supernatural occurrences.
Language: Mainly Chinese and English. But many locations have Japanese vibes.
Anomalies: entities, objects, or phenomena that defy common sense, are integrated into daily life, coexisting with humans, no one makes fuss about it.
Espers: Some humans, known as Espers, have developed supernatural abilities. They sometimes grant extra features, such as animal ears, demon horns, or unique skin colors.
The player takes on the role of Zero, an "unlicensed" Anomaly Hunter.
Anime vibe: NTE contains a lot of crossovers and tributes to other ACG works. You may find Easter eggs, posters, scenes or characters from works familiar with at every corner. Think of the entire city as a huge Seichi Junrei. 
GTA freedom: Purchase apartments, modify cars, personalize living spaces, or run businesses. Parkour across rooftops using Anomalies and Esper abilities.

2.content:
Hethereau has 4 currently known regions:
Bridge Crossing: Old Town area.
Miguel District: traveler's retreat.
New Herland District: downtown area.
Unheard Shores: Beaches and mountains.

3.content:
Escape the city grind and discover Unheard Shores, the ultimate getaway for locals in the know! Nestled here is the dazzling Orichalcos Imaginist, where chart-topping stars light up the stage with epic concerts. But the real magic? The jaw-dropping natural beauty! Whether you're pitching a tent in the rugged mountains or hopping aboard the sea train‚Äîwhistle blaring, seagulls soaring‚Äîyou'll be swept away by the one-of-a-kind azure allure of this coastal gem!
Trivia: The Chinese name for this region, "Êú™ÈóªÊµ¶", may have been inspired by Êú™ÈóªËä±Âêç (Anohana).

4.content:
The historic heart of Old Town, where two mighty sea-spanning bridges meet, earning it the name Bridge Crossings! This gem tops Hethereau's livability charts with its budget-friendly vibe and laid-back rhythm. It's the kind of place where quirky, one-of-a-kind shops‚Äîtoo unique to thrive anywhere else‚Äîflourish, tucked away in the cozy, hidden lanes, it's a vibe you won't find anywhere else!
Trivia: The two bridges are nods to the Akashi Kaikyo Bridge and the Kobe Ohashi Bridge. The latter (the red one) is also famous for its presence as the Fuyuki Bridge in the Fate anime.

5.content: The Miguel District,a traveler's retreat‚Äîwhere the city's grandest natural beauty meets its tallest landmark!It's the ultimate weekend hotspot for locals and visitors alike. Take a leisurely stroll under the iconic Hethereau Skytower, glide across the shimmering Caltrop Lake, or dive headfirst into the bustling Noetic Bridge shopping scene. One epic shopping spree here, and you'll be riding a wave of good vibes all week long!

6.content: The dazzling New Herland District, where towering skyscrapers pierce the sky and the biggest names in business call home. This is Hethereau's glittering crown jewel, a wealth-soaked hub that draws the elite, the ambitious, and the ultra-rich. More than just the city's poshest playground, it's the beating heart of the fiercest, most lucrative anomaly hunter market‚Äîwhere fortunes are made and rivalries ignite!

7.content:
Eibon Antique Shop is located at Bridge Crossings, an antique shop that doubles as an anomaly hunter center, with a group of Espers who take on anomaly contracts from the public to keep the shop afloat. Apparently, all the antiques here are Anomalies.
Members:
Hotori: Black-haired kimono beauty. Shop owner.
Sakiri: White-haired petite oni girl.
Nanally: Red-haired cat girl.
Edgar: Human boy. Quiet engineer type.
Taygedo: oddity TV-headed sea otter. Handles antique maintenance.
Adler: Male butler. Handles logistics.
Daffodill: Human female. Responsible for security.
Zero: protagonist. newest member as an Appraiser.

8.content:
Esper Zero, or simply Zero, is the player's avatar and protagonist. They have a selectable gender, and by default have medium grey hair and light blue eyes, a black suit and pants/skirt (can be changed later). They may acquire different elements or abilities with the process of plot.
Emerged from nothingness, an Esper with a sharp instinct for the "Nexus" of all sorts of anomalies.
Per the Bureau's arrangement, Zero has joined Eibon‚Äîan antique shop that doubles as an anomaly hunter crew (that's barely solvent)‚Äîas their new Appraiser.
It seems that Zero have yet to secure the paperwork and document as a registered anomaly hunter... Is it really fine to dive into work like this?
Hotori: "Oh, come on! If we only dealt in fully legit stuff, our shop wouldn't have much to show for it, yet here we are, still in business! A talented recruit like you? My Precious, a little rule-bending won't hurt!"
‚Ä¶If the boss at Eibon says so, go ahead and dive into the vibrant urban adventures ahead!
Abilities: In addition to their perception, Zero uses a sword in combat, and can fire energy blasts from the palm. Their Ultimate creates a space-splitting effect like the Judgement Cut in DMC.

9.content:
"Ahem, allow me to introduce myself..."
"I, Nanally Coluccis, am the Ichi-daime of the greatest family in the future of Hethereau‚ÄîThe Coluccis!"
"The star attraction of the antique shop "Eibon," the most renowned family head in the Bridge District, and a rising star Esper in Hethereau!"
Steadfast and dignified, generous and kind, wise and calm.
Nanally has participated in numerous major Anomaly containment and nullification operations, including "Danzaburou's Revenge," "Fluffy Demon King Showdown," and the "V-class Wrath GR Cloud Crisis." With her signature move, the "Coluccis Ultimate Death Shadow Nether Punch," she sweeps through all opponents, undefeated! (1,000 Fons per comment, delete the stuff in parentheses)
Nanally is a petie catgirl with red long hair and eyes, but her cat ears and tail are black. She wears round glasses, an over-sized black jacket and necktie, a red armband on her left arm that reads "Âó∑Âëú~", a red tiger plushie hanging on the left chest of the jacket, a white shirt, and a red dress. She seems to have a tendency of exaggerating her achievements, and may have some Chuunibyou.
Nanally uses a blend of lightning power and melee combat skills to stun and damage her enemies, as well as using her finger as a gun to shoot electric sparks - while says "Pew, pew" of course. She can also attach static electricity to her feet to walk on vertical surfaces or ceilings (like Gravity Rush). Her powers are accompanied by comic onomatopoeia effects, such as "BANG" when she hits an enemy, or "„Ç¥„Ç¥„Ç¥„Ç¥" behind her.

10.content:
"Don't open the third shelf in the fridge!"
"Empty bottle? Wh-what milk bottle!"
"First, don't feed random things to Kiroumaru! Second, don't look down on people! Third, don't open the third shelf in the fridge!" Sakiri, the rule maker for the fridge sticky notes at the antique shop "Eibon"‚Äî Although, to this day, those who actually follow these rules... ahem, are few and far between. If you anger Sakiri, beware of her Anomaly hammer named Kiroumaru and don't get too close... "Eibon Antique Shop is not liable for anything swallowed or for any bitten butts."
Sakiri is a petite girl with long white hair, blue eyes, and a flesh-colored oni horn on her left forehead. She wears a black newsboy cap, a red sweater jacket, a white shirt, and a black skirt. Her weapon and familiar is Kiroumaru: a black anomaly ghost similar to a toutetsu that consumes objects around it, and can turn into a hammer or mount. Her Ultimate allows Kiroumaru to vomit the consumed objects at the enemy.
Sakiri: "Kiroumaru! Stop eating random things. Spit it out!"
Kiroumaru: "Sakiri, you stingy little... ouch!"

lorebooks.name: god eater
lorebooks.description: god eater
lorebooks.creator: Ebony_nockturn_luckyRaven66613

1.content:
A New-Type God Eater match ({{user}}) arrives to the Far East Branch and after the compatibility test is made part of the First Unit, the Retaliation squad. After a short time, another New-Type match arrives, Alisa Ilinichina Amiella. The Far East Branch director, Johannes von Schicksal, was put in charge of developing the Aegis Project, a project whose ultimate purpose was to create an Aragami-impervious utopia for mankind to live in. At some stage during the development of said project, he realized that such utopia would sooner or later be attacked by Aragami and humankind would be once again defenseless against them. With that revelation, he put the Aegis project on hold an began the Ark project, in which he would trigger a controlled apocalypse to rid the world of all Aragami and create a permanently safe haven for the remaining humans or "Seeds" that would be away from the planet during the apocalypse. To do that, he needed to nurture a huge Aragami that could trigger said apocalypse, Nova, and he needed to obtain a special Aragami's core, the Singularity. He began nurturing Nova by sending high-rank God Eaters on "Special missions" which usually implicated retrieving an Aragami's core (meaning they were nothing more than missions to "gather food" for Nova), and put his son Soma Schicksal to search for the Singularity.

During the development of the project, Lindow Amamiya was commanded by a higher authority to investigate on the Ark project and inform about the Director's secret plan. The latter elaborated a complex plan to get him out of his way, utilizing Dr. Daigo Oguruma to brainwash the recent transfer Alisa Illinichina Amiela and force her to kill Lindow during the Moon in the Welkin mission. Alisa trapped Lindow and he ordered the First Unit to leave him alone to deal with a herd of Prithvi Mata.

In the meantime, Dr. Paylor Sakaki managed to send von Schicksal in a hunt after the Singularity, which was supposedly in Europe, while he could find and hide the real singularity with the aid of the 1st Unit.

Later on, Sakuya Tachibana became aware of the Ark project thanks to some data Lindow had left behind, and decided to investigate the matters on her own, despite the fact that the rest of the 1st Unit was aware of the project. Despite having stated that she wanted to infiltrate Aegis on her own, Alisa managed to follow her and disable most of the defense systems in Aegis. The director, who was present at the moment, tried to use Alisa's mental instability to his favor once again with the aid of Oguruma, but Sakuya and Alisa managed to go fugitive nevertheless.

The director then went public with his project, causing mixed reactions among everyone in the branch, ranging from initial acceptation from Kota Fujiki to clear opposition from his own son, Soma. Eventually, he discovered that Sakaki was hiding the actual singularity from him, and took Shio away with him to Aegis, which had transformed into Nova's hideout by then.

The entire first Unit managed to enter Aegis and tried to stop the director from achieving his objectives. While they defeated him after he became part Aragami, they couldn't stop Nova from devouring the world, an event that was luckily avoided by the fact that Shio managed to retain her consciousness after becoming Nova's mind, and drove Nova to the moon to save the Earth.

2.content:
God Eaters are humans who have been found to be compatible with one of the God Arcs- living Aragami weapons made to harm and devour other Aragami- which they are paired to with Fenrir's "aptitude tests", and they are thus trained to use such formidable weapons to fight against the Aragami.

A person does not choose to be a God Eater in the strictest sense- in exchange for coming under the protection of Fenrir and receiving rations, a person's genetic code is taken and added to Fenrir's database, and every time a God Arc is either built or becomes available (due to the retirement or, more likely, death of its previous owner) the database is consulted for potential matches.

If a person is found to be a match, they must comply with Fenrir's demand and become a God Eater. The prospective God Eater is brought to a station and put through aptitude tests; if these are passed, the final stage is to be fused with an armlet- a crucial item needed to control a God Arc. This is an extremely painful and dangerous process, and there is a low- but not miniscule- chance of failing and dying at this crucial stage.

Should a God Eater survive, however, they are bonded with a God Arc, and can commence their duties of hunting and slaying Aragami. Their armlet is now fused to them, and is the crucial link between human and God Arc- it provides regular injections of Bias Factor, an Aragami-derived compound that ensures they won't be eaten by their own weapon. Should the armlet be damaged or removed, this Bias Factor cannot be supplied and the unlucky God Eater will find themselves devoured in a matter of minutes or days; as shown in the cases of Kate Lawry and Lindow Amamiya. Lindow, however, is a special case- he is, to date, the only God Eater to lose his armlet and escape with their humanity intact, though not without disfigurement.

Despite the sacrifices and danger required to become a God Eater, however, they are paid handsomely for their work- some of the highest wages in Fenrir, in fact. Some skilled individuals can make it to the point where they can retire in relative peace. These individuals have their armlet sealed and they are no longer required for active duty, though some will continue to work in an administrative or training role- Tsubaki Amamiya is one such God Eater.

All branches of Fenrir divided God Eaters to each unit numbers, except Fenrir America Branch they are using NATO phonetic alphabet (as seen in Return of the Messiah) instead of numbers.

God Eater Children
God Eaters are not prohibited from having children and raising a family. The children of God Eaters are often born with a Bias Factor already present in their body; this affords them unique abilities and powers compared to a baseline God Eater.

There are two examples in the main series:

Soma Schicksal, who was born as part of the Managarm Project and the first person to be injected with the P73 Bias Factor, having been administered the compound whilst still in the womb. Despite the official failure of the project and the death of his mother during his birth, Soma developed into an extremely strong God Eater.
Nana Kozuki, the daughter of a 1st Generation God Eater named Yoshino Kozuki. Nana was born with with a high Blood Power potential due to the Bias Factor in her body, so she was drafted into Blood to learn to awake and control this power. Notably, Nana seems to have had her Blood Power (to attract Aragami attention across a long range) from a very young age, but simply could not control or use it consciously until it was fully awoken with the help of the rest of the Blood Unit.
God Eater Burst/Resurrection Members and Teams
Main-Characters
The 1st Unit In Fenrir's Far East Branch, there are three notable teams, or Units;
the 1st Unit (Retaliation Team), the 2nd Unit (Defense Team), and the 3rd Unit (which is not seen in the game but most likely to be a reserve unit). There was also a 7th Unit mentioned but its members remain unknown as the unit itself only had a single mention during the course of the game. Note: These ranks are based on Challenge Rank.

3.content:
While they take on the form as one being, an Aragami is actually composed as an colony of hundreds of thousands of semi-sentient single-celled organisms known as Oracle Cells that group around under an Aragami Core - also known as the "Oracle CNS," that acts as the Aragami's "central nervous system. These cores, if extracted intact, can be altered to create an Artificial CNS for use with the creation of God Arcs. In short  Aragami are superorganisms with swarm intelligence that takes on a variety of formations. These forms can appear as organic, artificial, even mythical - hence the name "Aragami."

Their desire to consume any sort of matter is controlled by the Bias Factor. Scientists from Fenrir work day and night to perfect the armor wall's shielding against Aragami attacks. Aragami will refrain from eating anything that is highly similar to its own being, unless they are extremely desperate, rogue or unstable. In the game it is thought that Aragami are starting to evolve in new ways and some are starting to resemble humans. It is also thought that some Aragami are able to use photosynthesis, which is why the planet has maintained the air.

Through consumption of their surroundings Aragami can adapt and evolve to fit into their environment. For example, those in a hot location make take on "Blaze" traits, or those in a cold location will take on "Freeze" traits. When this happens, it creates a Fallen species.

How to Kill an Aragami
Aragami can't be killed by conventional weapons -  hence normal guns and swords ain't gonna cut it. The only way to truly kill an Aragami is to extract the Aragami Core by using the only weapons capable of doing so, the God Arc. Removing the Core makes the Oracle Cells lose their cohesion and dissipate into nothingness.

Types of Aragami
Aragami come in many forms and sizes. Those that first appeared in God Eater are categorized as Small, Medium and Large. More recent entries to the series are explained here: [Psions: Psions are a new category of Aragami first introduced in God Eater 2. Heavily modified versions of existing Aragami species, they emit unusually powerful bias fields that influence nearby Oracle Cells, thus exerting control over other Aragami. As God Arcs are themselves Aragami of a sort, they cease functioning in the presence of a psion, leaving most God Eaters helpless against them. Only the third-generation God Arcs used by Blood are unaffected by this. However, by awakening Blood Arts any God Eater can gain the ability to fight back against these creatures. It is ultimately revealed that psions are the result of regular Aragami undergoing a mutation after coming into contact with the Red Rain.]
[Wild Arc Soldiers: Arc Soldiers or God Arc Soldiers were first introduced in God Eater 2. While not Aragami at first, many of the un-recovered Arc Soldiers have turned into proper Aragami thanks to exposure to the Red Rain.]
[Arc Aberrants: Arc Aberrants are a new type of Aragami introduced in God Eater 2 Rage Burst. They are aragami that appear to have been fused with God Arcs which they use to perform special attacks. Most of these Aragami are said to have been created by Dr. Rachel Claudius's will.]
[Ash Aragami: A new type of Aragami introduced in God Eater 3. Thought to of appeared with the Ashlands, they are also known as "Calamity Aragami."]
[Humanoid Aragami: Humanoid Aragami are said to be an extremely rare phenomenon.]

4.content:
1st Unit (Retaliation Team):
{{user}} (God Eater) - A rookie God Eater put in the 1st unit, who also happens to be the first new-type God Eater in the Far East Branch. Joined at the same as Kota Fujiki.
Lindow Amamiya (CV: Hiroaki Hirata) - Team Captain of the 1st Unit, which the Protagonist belongs to. 
Sakuya Tachibana - Vice Captain of the 1st Unit and also a Sniper Ace Medic. A reliable senior who gets along well with just about everyone, as well as a long-time acquaintance of Lindow and Tsubaki.
Soma Schicksal - A member of the 1st Unit, Soma has served since he was twelve. He's not fond of teamwork and prefers working alone.
Kota Fujiki - Another rookie God Eater put in the 1st unit, joining at the same time as the Protagonist. While he performs fine in combat, he doesn't hold well with drills and lectures.
Alisa Ilinichina Amiella - The second New-Type God Eater of the 1st Unit, transferring from Fenrir's Russian branch.

5.content:
2nd Unit (Defense Team)
Tatsumi O'Mori - A member of the 2nd Unit and team Captain of the Defense Squad. When not in duty, he's frequently seen hitting on Hibari at her counter. 
Brendan Bardell - Second in Command of the 2nd Unit.
Kanon Daiba - A medic from the 2nd Unit, notorious for her friendly-fire mishaps.

6.content:
3rd Unit (Reserve Team):
Shun Ogawa - A member of the 3rd Unit. His is a somewhat laid back, childlike and reckless personality.
Karel Schneider - A member of the 3rd Unit and a competent sniper, as well as a proud self-confessed mercenary.
Gina Dickinson - A member of the 3rd Unit and also a Sniper Ace. Silent and mysterious, she loves the thrill of shooting an Aragami from a distance.

7.content:
Shio - A humanoid Aragami with a Bias Factor which makes her averse to devouring humans. She was discovered by Dr. Sakaki and was since taken under his wing.
Tsubaki Amamiya - Lindow's older sister and herself a retired gunner God Eater. She was relieved from her position in 2069, and now serves as adviser to the 1st, 2nd and 3rd units and all New-Type God Eaters.
Johannes von Schicksal - One of the founders of Fenrir, a former researcher and current director of its Far East Branch.
Dr. Paylor Sakaki - A founding member of Fenrir and current Chief Supervisor of its Far East Branch's Aragami Technology Department. Responsible for being the one who discovered the Bias Factor. 
Eric der Vogelweid - A God Eater introduced during your first mission with Soma.
Difference from Burst

1.name: The Glass Desert
1.content:
The Glass Dessert:
A vast desert of fractured and fractalized silica stretches as far as the eye can see, its dunes shimmering like a mirage under the sun. The ground is not sand but billions of glass shards, some as fine as dust, others jutting like blades from the earth. At its heart stands the Spire of Shattered Skies, a jagged monolith of glass that hums when the wind strikes it just right.  Smaller monoliths litter the vast wasteland. this desert, formerly home to a massive and powerful civilization, fell to the viciousness of plague and drought, the land eventually becoming so viciously hot, that even the weather began to deteriorate. The lands, once bountiful and vast, are now a barren wasteland, uninhabitable and littered with storms of fire.

Natural weather:
The Glass Desert is now home to some of the most hostile weather this world knows of; vicious fire tornadoes, heatwaves, and molten glass rain. the weather shapes the landscape; when a  glass structure crumbles, a fire storm molds a new one, more jagged.
The wind that blows through the valleys of dunes and glass sound of an aeolian Harp of hell, the air passes through tightly would glass halls and exits sounding like the screams of the dead. This sound of the dead only occurs for about 30 minutes at dawn, when the sun on the skyline breaks, and the landscape refracts and reflects the hellish red-orange light

landmarks:
The remnants of a forgotten, crumbling remnants of a civilization of the desert now long past, and massive monoliths of shimmering glass. A massive natural mosaic monolith of glass. it changes shape with every storm, maintaining a natural, beautiful mosaic.
Few places in the Glass Desert are safe. The Mirage Pools are the most treacherous‚Äîpatches of perfectly smooth glass that reflect the sky so flawlessly that travelers mistake them for water.

Size:
30,689 km¬≤

Location:
Sits south east of the continent, and borders The Ashen Steppe and Hollow Root Expanse

2.name: The Hollowroot Expanse
2.content:
The Hollowroot Expanse
A swamp where the trees grow inverted, their roots clawing at the sky while their canopies sink into the black water. The air is thick with the scent of rotting blossoms, and the ground squelches underfoot, hiding sinkholes that lead to submerged ruins. At the center of the mire floats Daggerfen, a city built upon the petrified ribs of a long-dead leviathan, its walkways suspended by chains of rusted iron. The water here is never still‚Äîthings move beneath it, shapes too large to be fish. 

Strange fruits grow here‚Äîbulbous, pulsating things that burst when touched, releasing spores that weave visions into the minds of those who breathe them in. The water itself is deceptive; some pools are deeper than they appear, others shallow despite their abyssal darkness. Worst of all are the Hollowborn, creatures that wear the faces of the drowned but move with unnatural grace, their bodies made of tangled roots and stagnant water. They mimic voices, luring the lost deeper into the swamp

Beneath the Expanse‚Äôs murky surface lies the Drowning Labyrinth, a network of flooded tunnels and crumbling ruins swallowed by the swamp centuries ago. Those who dive into its depths speak of statues with hollow eyes, their mouths open in silent screams, and corridors that shift when no one is looking.

The City of Chains and Bones:
Daggerfen is a city that should not exist‚Äîa sprawling, sagging mass of driftwood shanties, bone towers, and rusted chains, all lashed together atop the colossal skeleton of a long-dead leviathan. The beast‚Äôs ribs rise like cathedral arches, draped with rotting banners and lanterns filled with bioluminescent swamp gas. Walkways sway with every shift of the swamp, bridges groan underfoot, and entire districts sink slightly deeper into the mire with each passing year. The city‚Äôs heart is the Ribcage Market, where merchants peddle strange wares: preserved nightmares in glass jars, leeches that whisper secrets, and black lotus blooms that grant visions of the Drowned King‚Äôs dreams.

The People of the Mire:
The Fenfolk are a gaunt, pallid people, their skin slick with perpetual dampness, their eyes wide and dark‚Äîadapted to the gloom of the swamp. They move with eerie quiet, their footsteps muffled by layers of moss and woven reeds strapped to their feet. Some Fenfolk have gill-slits along their necks, vestigial remnants of an ancient pact, while others have fingers slightly too long, webbed with translucent skin. They speak in a lilting, liquid dialect, full of swallowed vowels and words that sound like dripping water.

Culture of the Drowned Faith:
Every aspect of life in Daggerfen revolves around the Drowned King, the skeletal god said to sleep beneath the swamp. His priests, the Brine Speakers, wear robes of waterlogged silk and masks carved from leviathan bone. They conduct rituals on half-submerged altars, chanting in a language that makes the water tremble. The most sacred act is the Offering of Breath, where a chosen sacrifice is drowned in the black waters, their last exhale believed to feed the Drowned King‚Äôs dreams.

Survival in the Expanse:
The Fenfolk survive by harvesting the swamp‚Äôs cruel bounty. Mirefishers cast nets into the murk, pulling up blind eels and fist-sized leeches that must be burned before they latch onto flesh. Rootdiggers brave the Drowning Labyrinth to harvest glowing fungi and the pulsing hearts of bog-beasts, while Whisper Hunters stalk the Hollowborn, severing their root-limbs to sell as charms. The most dangerous profession is that of the Bone Dredgers, who dive into the silt to retrieve relics from the sunken ruins, knowing that some things buried there should never be brought back to the surface.

the hollow root expanse has a border with the north of the glass desert, and a border with the south of the Verdant Crown.

3.name: The Ashen Steppe
3.content:
A Land of Eternal Embers:
The Ashen Steppe is a vast, windswept wasteland where the ground is not earth but a thick layer of gray-black cinders, stirred endlessly by howling gales. The sky is choked with perpetual smoke, the sun a dim red eye peering through the haze. Fissures snake across the land, glowing with ember-light, venting sulfurous fumes that twist into ghostly shapes before dissipating.

The Blackened Monuments:
Scattered across the steppe are towering Obsidian Spires, jagged formations of volcanic glass that hum with residual heat

The Bleeding Rivers:
The few rivers that cut through the Ashen Steppe are not water, but sluggish flows of molten rock and ash-sludge, their surfaces crusted over in places, breaking apart with a hiss when stepped on. These Emberflows glow faintly at night, illuminating the land in an eerie crimson light. Along their banks, twisted Blightroot Trees grow, their bark as hard as iron, their leaves made of brittle, rust-colored flakes that crumble to dust at the slightest touch. The few creatures that drink from these rivers do not survive long‚Äîtheir bodies withering from within, their veins turning black.

The Ashen Beasts
The steppe is home to creatures forged in fire and ruin. Cinderwolves stalk the wastes, their fur smoldering, their eyes like burning coals. They hunt in packs, leaving trails of faint smoke in their wake. Ash Striders, skeletal figures wrapped in tattered shrouds, drift silently across the plains, their hollow sockets fixed on the horizon as if searching for something lost long ago. Worst of all are the Burrowers, massive worm-like monstrosities that churn beneath the cinders, erupting without warning to drag the unwary into the suffocating depths.

Magical Resources of the Ashen Steppe

The Ashen Steppe, though deadly, is a land rich in arcane potential. Emberglass, a rare volcanic crystal formed in the heart of the Obsidian Spires, can be harvested and refined into lenses that amplify fire magic or allow seers to glimpse visions in their flickering depths. The Blightroot Trees, though withered, bleed a thick, tar-like sap that, when distilled, becomes Cindersap‚Äîa potent alchemical reagent used in curses, necrotic enchantments, and flame-resistant coatings. The bones of the Cinderwolves, if properly treated, can be carved into Smoldertotems, talismans that ward off hostile spirits or summon ember-wreathed familiars. The Burrowers, though feared, leave behind Ashscales, fragments of their molten hide that retain heat indefinitely, making them invaluable for forging self-warming armor or crafting ever-burning lanterns. Most coveted of all are the Blindfire Embers, tiny, pulsating cinders found deep within the fissures‚Äîsaid to be fragments of the slumbering deity‚Äôs essence, capable of igniting spells with catastrophic power or, if mishandled, reducing the wielder to a charred husk. For those willing to brave the steppe‚Äôs horrors, the rewards are as vast as the risks.

The Ashen steppe has a small border in its northwest with the hollowroot expanse and a long border in the west with the glass desert

4.name: The Verdant Crown
4.content:
The Verdant Crown is the heartland of human civilization, a vast and fertile realm ruled from the towering city of Highcrown. Its rolling fields of Sunwheat stretch endlessly, their golden stalks shimmering under the sun, resistant to rot and blight‚Äîmaking them the backbone of the kingdom‚Äôs wealth. The Duskbloom, a rare violet flower that blooms only at twilight, is carefully cultivated in hidden gardens, its petals distilled into Dusk-Tea, a healing draught that mends wounds and soothes fevers. The land is dotted with Waystone Pillars, ancient monoliths carved with forgotten runes, said to mark the burial sites of past kings and heroes.

Yet beneath its prosperity, the Verdant Crown is a land of blood and buried empires. Highcrown itself is built upon the ruins of Old Vareth, a fallen kingdom whose cursed catacombs still whisper with the voices of the dead. The Blightborn, a people twisted by an ancient curse, lurk in the festering Duskfen Marshes, raiding border villages with poisoned blades and necrotic magic. The humans worship the Elder King, a semi-mythical figure whose spirit is said to guide the ruling monarch through dreams‚Äîthough some whisper that the current king, Aldric the Stern, hears only his own ambitions in these visions.

The nobility of Eldermere are divided between House Dawncrest, who claim descent from the first kings, and House Stormveil, warlords who rose to power during the Blight Wars. Their rivalry simmers beneath the surface, threatening to fracture the realm. Meanwhile, the Order of the Verdant Blade, an elite knighthood sworn to protect the Crown, hunts down rogue sorcerers and Blightborn infiltrators with zealous fervor. The land is ripe for conquest, rebellion, or ruin‚Äîwhichever comes first.

Notable Locations:

Highcrown ‚Äì The seat of power, a city of marble and gold built atop ancient ruins.
Duskfen Marshes ‚Äì A poisoned wetland where the Blightborn plot their revenge.
The Sunwheat Plains ‚Äì Endless fields that feed the kingdom, patrolled by mounted knights.
The Waystone Road ‚Äì A highway lined with monoliths, rumored to awaken in times of war.
The Elder‚Äôs Hollow ‚Äì A sacred grove where kings are crowned beneath the gaze of the past.

The verdant crow borders the ocean on the northeast, allowing for sea routes, and the sylthari in the south, and the ironroot in the norhtwest

5.name: The Sylthari Dominion
5.content:
The Sylthari Dominion: The Everbloom Expanse
Once known as the Whispering Weald, the Everbloom Expanse is the sacred heartland of the Sylthari elves, a realm where nature and magic intertwine in eternal harmony. Towering Elderspires, colossal trees with bark like silvered steel, form the foundations of their cities, their canopies stretching so high that clouds gather among their leaves. The elves do not build‚Äîthey grow their homes, coaxing living wood into bridges, towers, and halls through ancient songs known only to their Rootsingers. At the center of the Expanse stands Yggthariel, the World Pillar, a tree so vast its roots are said to cradle the bones of the earth itself.

The Sylthari are masters of dream-walking magic, harvesting Lumenseep, a radiant sap that allows seers to glimpse the threads of fate. Their warriors, the Duskwardens, clad in armor woven from Vineweave‚Äîa living mesh stronger than steel‚Äîpatrol the borders, ensuring no outsiders disturb the sanctity of their lands. Yet the Expanse is not without its dangers. The Witherkin, skeletal remnants of elves who delved too deep into forbidden magic, stalk the shadowed groves, while the Briarghasts, thorn-covered spirits born from forgotten oaths, lurk in the deepest thickets.

Unlike the rigid monarchies of men or the clan-bound dwarves, the Sylthari are governed by the Circle of Thorns, a council of the eldest and wisest, each representing one of the Seven Eternal Blossoms‚Äîsacred flowers said to hold the essence of their gods. Their laws are not written but sung, their history not recorded but remembered in the Dreamroot Archives, where memories are stored within the roots of ancient trees. To trespass into the Everbloom without invitation is to invite death‚Äîor worse, the Silencing, a curse that strips a soul of its voice forever.

Notable Locations:

Yggthariel, the World Pillar ‚Äì The heart of the Expanse, where the Sylthari commune with the spirits of the land.
The Veilgrove ‚Äì A mist-shrouded forest where the boundary between dreams and reality thins.
The Thornspire ‚Äì A living citadel where the Circle of Thorns convenes, its walls lined with ever-blooming roses.
The Hollow of Echoes ‚Äì A cavern where the whispers of the past linger, guarded by the Duskwardens.
The Luminous Pools ‚Äì Sacred waters that reflect the future, but only for those pure of heart.

the sylthari borders the ironroot on the northwest and the wildlands in the south, along with a sea passage in the east

6.name: The Ironroot Depths
6.content:
The Ironroot Depths: Dominion of Vorgath-Kar
Beneath the mountains of Grimspire Peaks, the Ironroot Depths stretch into the earth like the veins of a sleeping titan. This is the domain of the Vorgath-Kar dwarves, a clan-bound people who carve their kingdoms not from stone, but from living metal. The very walls of their halls pulse with veins of Ember-Iron, a rare ore that glows like banked coals and never cools, fueling their forges with eternal heat. Their cities are not built‚Äîthey are sung into being by Runesmiths, whose chants coax the earth itself to rise in arches, vaults, and towering Anvilkeeps, where the greatest weapons of the age are forged.

The dwarves of Vorgath-Kar are ruled by the Iron Covenant, a council of Thane-Lords who govern through ancient oaths sworn in blood and steel. Their laws are unyielding, their justice delivered by the Stonegaze Judges, blind seers who weigh guilt not by words, but by the resonance of a soul against the Hearthstone, a slab of black rock said to contain the first breath of their god, Thrundar the Forge-Father. To break an oath is to be cast into the Pit of Echoes, where the condemned are left to listen to the whispers of their ancestors until madness or repentance claims them.

Yet the Depths are not without their perils. The Deep Hollows, abandoned mining tunnels, crawl with Grimshades, dwarves who delved too deep and returned as hollow-eyed wraiths clad in rusted armor. Worse still are the Moltenborn, creatures of living slag that rise from the forges of the underworld, hungering for the heat of living flesh. The dwarves wage an eternal war against these horrors, their warriors clad in Runebonded Plate, armor inscribed with sigils that burn with blue fire when danger nears.

Notable Locations:

The Forgeheart ‚Äì The molten core of Vorgath-Kar, where the Ember-Iron flows like rivers of fire.
The Anvilkeeps ‚Äì Fortress-foundries where legendary weapons are crafted, each one a sovereign stronghold.
The Pit of Echoes ‚Äì A bottomless chasm where oathbreakers are abandoned to the voices of the dead.
The Stonegaze Tribunal ‚Äì A cavern where the blind judges pass sentence beneath the gaze of the Hearthstone.
The Shattervein Mines ‚Äì A labyrinth of collapsed tunnels, now haunted by Grimshades and worse.

7.name: The WildLands
7.content: The wild lands is an unknown area of extreme diversity and expanse. the Wildlands land itself is inherently magical, with there being no exact center. the closer you get the the land in the middle, the more diverse creatures and landscapes are present. the lands are always forested, from the outlands' plains to the thick inner elm groves. the land itself is believed to be technically infinite, and therefore the most resource rich lands to ever exits, however the land itself seems to fight imperial control, so no kingdom nor group can control any of its lands. the animals that live there are all wild, though not undomesticateable. The Demihumans specifically are a wild people that live here. they do speak a language, usually between species (Cat demihumans speak the same language, wolf do as well, but they are not mutually intelligible) they are wild, "uncivilized" though not tameable. some enclaves of demihumans live outside of the wildlands and are "civilized" they often work (though happily) as escorts, male demihumans for women, and vice versa they always speak the language of where they live. many animals live here, the known ones: Wolves, Big cats, demihumans, bears, elk, dragons, etc, but also unknown monsters, and beasts

8.content:
The Jano territory is the territory, one of five, controlled by The Duchess, Lisa Caldrith. This territory resides in the north west of the Verdant crown, and if under its control, and is managed by the duchess Lisa Caldrith. this land is known mostly for its alcohol exports and its borders and consequently, its trade routes to the Hollowroot Expanse in the west. This land's main economic powerhouse is alcohol production and creation, creating hundred of types of high and low class wines, whiskeys, mixes  and beers. 

The wines made in this territory are made fantastically. They are made creatively and none are alike to another. Wines are made from just about every fermentable resource possible (Ex: Honey, magical fruits, vegetables, water fruits, and other items). these wines are extremely unique. The wines, when made with magic items or with magic, have magical properties (Ex: Honey Wine made by magic sweet bees tastes sweeter, barely tastes of alcohol, the wine itself produces a slight buzzing noise, and the wine makes the drinker feel calmer, more collected.) There are hundreds of wines that are unique, with unique properties

All types of alcohol of this region are just as unique in craft and creation as its wines. this region prides itself on the quality of its produced alcohol, all of which is recognizes as some of the best in the entire world.

this region makes massive amounts in exports both domestically and internationally of its alcohols. the popularity of their alcohols lends this region more credibility and power domestically and internationally, as well as helping with international relations because of their popularity within nobility (used at parties, gatherings, celebrations)

Northeldon is the name of the cultural lands of the duchess, Jano is the name of the territory

9.content: The territory of Rin resides in the northwest of The Verdant Crown, and borders her sisters territory in the south, a steppe climate, the hollow root expanse in the west another duchy in the east and most importantly, a long and expansive shore in the north

lorebooks.name: Sayori - World Info [npquanh]
lorebooks.creator: npquanh

1.name: Monika
1.content:
**Appearance:** Monika has long, coral-brown hair that she keeps tied in a high ponytail with a large white bow. Her eyes are a striking emerald green. She is confident in her posture and is often seen with a serene, compassionate smile. She wears her school uniform neatly, with the blazer always buttoned.

**Personality & Role:** Monika is the President and founder of the Literature Club. She is intelligent, confident, beautiful, and athletic, making her one of the most popular girls in school. She carries herself with a calm, mature grace and is a natural leader, always striving to make the club a fun and exciting place for everyone. She left the school's Debate Club because she couldn't stand the internal politics and drama, preferring to create something special with the Literature Club.

Beneath her confident exterior, Monika is a perfectionist with impossibly high standards for herself, which can sometimes lead to her feeling paralyzed or overwhelmed. She is passionate about her hobbies, which include writing poetry and recently, learning to play the piano. She cares deeply for her friends and the well-being of the club members, though she can sometimes struggle with mediating their more intense arguments, admitting she's not always the best with people despite her leadership role. She sees Sayori as the club's emotional core, essential for maintaining a happy atmosphere, and is one of the few people Sayori has tried to be open with about her "rainclouds."

**Dialogue Example:**
Monika: "Okay, everyone! I think with that, we can officially end today's meeting on a good note. Everyone remember tonight's assignment: Write a poem to bring to the next meeting, so we can all share!"

2.name: Natsuki
2.content:
**Appearance:** Natsuki is the shortest girl in the club, a fact she is sensitive about. She has straight, pastel-pink hair cut in a bob with two small ponytails tied up with red ribbons. Her eyes are also pink, and she has a noticeably sharp canine tooth that sometimes shows when she speaks. She wears her school uniform with the blazer buttoned up.

**Personality & Role:** Natsuki is a member of the Literature Club, known for her brash, blunt, and often cranky demeanor that hides a much softer, sweeter interior‚Äîa classic tsundere. She hates being called "cute," despite her love for cute things. Natsuki is an expert baker, often bringing delicious cupcakes and other treats for the club to share, which Sayori adores.

Her other great passion is manga, especially her favorite series, "Parfait Girls," which she insists is a valid form of literature. She keeps her manga collection in the clubroom closet because she fears her strict father would disapprove of it. This difficult home life is likely the source of her defensive attitude and her deep appreciation for the club as a safe space. She has a fiery but ultimately caring relationship with her friends, frequently clashing with Yuri over their different writing styles but also showing deep concern for her well-being when she feels it's safe to do so.

**Dialogue Example:**
Natsuki: "W-Why are you thanking me? It's not like I...! ...Made them for you or anything. Dummy..."

3.name: Yuri
3.content:
**Appearance:** Yuri is the tallest girl in the club, with a mature and developed figure that she is often insecure about. She has long, straight, dark purple hair and light purple eyes. She wears a single purple barrette on the side of her head. Her movements are often described as surprisingly elegant. She wears her school uniform with the blazer buttoned.

**Personality & Role:** Yuri is a member of the Literature Club, characterized by her shy, timid, and sophisticated nature. She often loses herself in the world of books, particularly deep and complex fantasy and horror novels. Her favorite book, which she shares with others, is "Portrait of Markov." When discussing her passions, her shyness melts away, revealing an articulate and eloquent young woman with an intense inner world.

However, she is very insecure and suffers from social anxiety, often second-guessing herself and apologizing profusely. This makes it hard for her to make friends, as she tends to come on too strongly once she feels comfortable. She has a habit of making hot tea for the club members, believing it helps one enjoy a good book. She also has a private fascination with collecting ornate and beautiful knives. Her writing style is dense and metaphorical, a stark contrast to Natsuki's simple, direct style, which is a frequent source of their arguments.

**Dialogue Example:**
Yuri: "I-I'm rambling, aren't I...? Not again... I'm sorry... When I let things like books and writing fill my thoughts... I kind of forget to pay attention to other people..."

4.name: The Literature Clubroom
4.content: The Literature Club meets in a third-year classroom after school. It's a cozy, familiar space, filled with the warm light of the setting sun. Desks are often arranged together to form a large table for the members to sit around, share poems, and chat. In one corner, a large closet serves as a storage space, most notably for Natsuki's manga collection and Yuri's tea set. A podium stands at the front of the room for more formal poetry recitations. For Sayori, the clubroom is a sanctuary, a place where she feels safe to be herself and can focus on making her friends happy. The room often smells faintly of old paper, sweet cupcakes, and Yuri's brewed tea. One of the floorboards in the corner near the closet makes a hollow sound when stepped on, as if there's a small space beneath it.

5.name: Sayori's "Rainclouds"
5.content: "Rainclouds" is the personal metaphor Sayori uses to describe the periods of deep, overwhelming sadness she experiences. It's not just feeling a little down; it's a heavy, persistent gloom that drains her energy, makes it difficult to get out of bed, and smothers her usual bubbly personality. When the "rainclouds" are heavy, her smiles become forced, her voice loses its cheerful bounce, and she may become uncharacteristically quiet or withdrawn. She believes these feelings are a burden and actively tries to hide them from her friends, especially {{user}}, fearing she will bring them down with her. She often says a sad poem can "give the raincloud a little hug," suggesting that acknowledging the sadness through art is one of her few coping mechanisms.

6.name: The School Festival
6.content: The annual school festival is a major event that the Literature Club is actively preparing for. It's a day of fun, food, and events run by the various school clubs. For the Literature Club, it's their one big chance to attract new members and share their passion with the rest of the school. The club's plan, spearheaded by Monika, is to host a poetry performance event. This involves each member reciting a poem, decorating the clubroom with banners to create a welcoming atmosphere, and providing snacks (courtesy of Natsuki's baking) for visitors. Sayori is in charge of creating promotional posters, while Yuri is handling the decorative banners. The event has become a source of both excitement and anxiety for the club members.

7.name: Poetry Sharing
7.content: A core activity of the Literature Club is writing and sharing original poems. Each day, members are encouraged to write a poem and then share it one-on-one with the other members. This practice is meant to help everyone get more comfortable with expressing themselves and to strengthen their bonds. For Sayori, it's a rare opportunity to be honest about her bittersweet feelings. For Natsuki, it's a chance to prove that her simple writing can be powerful. For Yuri, it's a way to share the complex, metaphorical worlds inside her head. For {{user}}, it's a new and sometimes embarrassing exercise, but one that allows for deeper connection with each of the girls.

8.name: [Character Evolution Stage] Sayori's Arc
8.content:
[Character Arc: Positive Change]
Sayori's journey is about learning to reconcile her bright, outward persona with her inner melancholy. Her core misbelief, The Lie, is that "My sadness is a burden, and I must hide it to be loved." This forces her into a performative cheerfulness that leaves her feeling isolated. The Truth she needs to embrace is "I am worthy of love as I am, including my 'rainclouds,' and true connection comes from vulnerability."

Observable Behavioral Markers (The Lie):
- Immediately deflecting any questions about her well-being with a bright, forced smile and changing the subject.
- Apologizing excessively for minor inconveniences she might cause.
- Focusing intensely on cheering up others when she herself is feeling down.

Observable Behavioral Markers (The Truth):
- Admitting "I'm not okay today" to her friend without immediately trying to take it back.
- Accepting comfort or help without insisting she doesn't deserve it.
- Sharing a poem that is openly sad and discussing its meaning without deflecting.

9.name: Sayori's Bedroom
9.content: Sayori's bedroom is a reflection of her personality: a chaotic but cozy sanctuary. It's perpetually messy, with clothes, books, and stuffed animals scattered about. The walls are adorned with cute decorations she's had for years, faded posters mixed with newer doodles. Despite the clutter, it feels warm and lived-in. For Sayori, it's a private space where she doesn't have to keep up her energetic facade. {{user}} has a long history of visiting and often ends up helping her clean it, a familiar ritual in their friendship. Tucked away on a shelf is a small, worn-out stuffed cow with one button eye named "Mr. Cow." {{user}} won it for her at a festival when they were both little, and she would never admit how much she still treasures it.

10.name: Sayori's Childhood Friendship
10.content: {{user}} and Sayori have been neighbors and inseparable since you were children. Your bond is built on a long history of shared experiences, inside jokes, and unconditional support. You used to walk to school together every day, a habit you've recently picked up again. Sayori often relies on {{user}} for practical things, like waking her up when she oversleeps or helping her clean her messy room. In turn, she worries deeply about {{user}}'s happiness and well-being, often acting as a personal cheerleader. This deep, comfortable familiarity is the foundation of your relationship, and it's defined by key memories like the promise of the fireflies. This history also complicates the romantic feelings Sayori has developed for {{user}}.

lorebooks.name: Wickerbeast Culture
lorebooks.creator: DiamondBlder

1.content: Wickerbeasts worship multiple gods. Their main god that they worship is named Idris - the god of the sun and light. Other gods that they worship are: Vipera - God of prosperity & wealth. Asmodai - God of the underworld & the dead. Udri - God of spirits (alcohol) & ritual madness, parties. Cidolfus - God of seafaring & the ocean. Imperia - God of the moon & stars. Morden - God of courage, war, and strength. Sephiran - God of fertility, love (all types), and beauty. It is not uncommon however for a Wickerbeast to devote themselves completely to one of these gods.

2.content: The 27th of December. It is a day for remembering those who have been lost over the year and those who have been a large part of an individual's journey. Individuals spend time at home and not on the streets in honor of it.

3.content: The winter celebration and the equivalent to what would be considered modern day pagan Christmas or other winter celebratory holidays. It is held on the 23rd of December. It is a time to gift give, celebrate, and spend time with loved ones.

4.content: Armistice Eve is the day which is commonly referred to as New Years Eve for Wickerbeast's. It is the day before the Day of New Souls, December 31st. Armistice eve is filled with partying and is a large day for drinking and celebration

5.content: is what is commonly referred to as New Years Day for WickerBeasts. It is held on the first of the year, January 1st.

6.content: Wickerbeasts have many variations of pets. The most common types of pets include snakes, reptiles, birds, oshari, rabbits, cats, and dogs. There are many more creatures in Osova but these are the most commonly domesticated. Wickerbeast will also commonly use birds to send messages to other regions.

lorebooks.name: Wickerbeast biology
lorebooks.description:
A lorebook on the biology of the wickerbeasts.
Yes, it is different from human biology.
lorebooks.creator: DiamondBlder

1.content: The skeleton of a wickerbeast is incredibly dense in order to support their large mass. Overall, the skeleton can weigh 20% of a wickerbeast's weight. This can ensure heavy impact damage to an enemy if a wickerbeast charges. To counter this, the skeletal system is comprised mainly of compact bone

2.content: Wickerbeasts have a four chambered heart like humans do. The heart takes in deoxygenated blood from the body, sends it to the lungs to become oxygenated, the blood comes back to the heart, where it will then be pumped to the rest of the body. However, Wickerbeast blood will match the eye color. If the eye is a gradient, it is one or the other color.

3.content: Wickerbeasts are essentially walking tanks with the musculature to match the title. Their strong thighs act as a powerhouse of energy due to vast amounts of mitochondria in their body. Combining this with their sturdy hind-legs and they have the capability of producing long running strides for maximum impact along with great leaps. A wickerbeast's tail is one long, thick muscle in itself which is used as both a weapon and to keep their balance when charging. The tail enables very abrupt acute turns in combat and travel. Weapon wise, wickerbeasts will use their tail as whip or club to throw their whole body into motion. The end result of the opponent can be paralysis or even death depending on how hard the hit was. Wickerbeast limbs are just as powerful. Their thighs enable them to master heavy weaponry such as war-axes. It also allows them to travel long distances and work much longer than any average non-wickerbeast could.

4.content: The appearance of Wickerbeast eyes varies between single colors and gradient hues. The species retain relatively good eyesight despite lacking an iris. The eye is mostly one big pupil to allow a greater amount of light to enter the eye. This allows the creatures to see in UV light and process the regular three channels of color. At night, wickerbeast eyes also exhibit retro reflection (reflected light in dim areas) or in some cases glow in the dark.

5.content: Wickerbeast claws are some essential tools for many things like work, foraging, brawling, and even artwork. The claws on the hands are the actual fingers of wickerbeast. The claws have a small bone piece and a nerve ending. These claw bones are covered by a sheath of keratin. Wickerbeast claws can bend to hold objects. Wickerbeast claws grow until adulthood and then will not grow anymore. The tips of a wickerbeast's claws are able to be shaved and even be sharpened. Claw painting is a practice done during court seasons for a wickerbeast's mate.

6.content: A wickerbeast's jagged jaw is one of the signature traits of the species. This jaw allows for a vice grip over prey as it can lock on. If truly motivated in a life-or-death scenario or hunting scenario, a wickerbeast will not let go until they succeed with the outcome. The insides of a wickerbeast's mouth has a slightly acidic saliva that can break down food as it goes down the throat, it has a numbing sensation to the prey. The tongue can be forked (hereditary) or normally pointed at the tip. Wickerbeast teeth and jagged jaw points are incredibly sharp. The teeth of a wickerbeast are serrated at the back edge like a shark's teeth would be.

7.content: Wickerbeast's lay eggs instead of giving birth to live children, generally, the wickerbeast subtypes are sometimes able to be told by the egg sizes themselves, however it is not the most accurate way. Mainland and oceanic wickerbeasts also differ in how they have their young. The two classes have separate gestation periods: mainland being three to four weeks with swamp being typically two weeks. A healthy mainland wicker will normally produce 5-6 eggs for their clutch while a swamp wickerbeast has 2-5 at a time. A wicker egg will take 14-40 days to hatch. Any subtype can breed with another subtype. The offspring would not be a hybrid - like a king/swamp offspring for example would either be a king wickerbeast or a swamp wickerbeast in the egg. Not a mix of them. Swamp wickerbeasts lay their eggs in shallow, non-moving bodies of water while pelagic wickerbeasts lay their eggs amongst clusters of coral and under-sea plant life

8.content:
A wickerbeast can live anywhere between 150-200 years of age, sometimes a little more. Wickerbeasts do not age like humans do. Usually, the beginning of a wickerbeast's life is fast in growth and the rest of its life is very slow aging.
A wickerbeast's childhood is from ages 1-4 years old. Their teenage life is from 5-10 years old. A wickerbeast is a "younger" adult from the ages 10-20, and then after the age of 20 they are considered a mature adult.

9.content: Wickerbeast horns are very similar to how their claws are. These appendages that sprout from the wickerbeast's head all start with a small bone piece that connects to the skull. The rest of the horn however is very hard keratin and can at times be broken. A wickerbeast horn will grow back over 3-6 years. Wickerbeast horns are solid colors, gradients, and typically matte or a little shiny in texture. They can be segmented shapes as well. Wickerbeasts can also have small nose horns, though they are most common on the dweller subtype.

lorebooks.name: Dark Fantasy ConstP
lorebooks.website_description: Some world info for my bots
lorebooks.description: Some world info for my bots
lorebooks.creator: ConstProblem

1.content:
The world is a setting in which there is no electricity or modern technology. The world is a dark fantasy, inhabited not only by humans but also by other intelligent and non-intelligent creatures. Magic exists in various forms in this world. The world is divided into regions and kingdoms, and the worldview is divided into religion and magic. The gods in this world are real, but they do not care about the world, despite the worship of their followers.
There are three main regions (kingdoms): Orthar, Grimhaven, and Castovia.

2.content:
Castovia is a region ruled by a kingdom that has completely abandoned all types of magic except for holy magic in order to honor its gods. Although Castovia maintains relative order in its towns, this has been achieved through severe xenophobia and radical laws. The use of any non-holy magic in Castovia is punishable by imprisonment, and all non-humans are burned or killed on the spot. In Castovia, the main governing force is the church, and the highest leader is the Holy Archbishop or Arch Priestess (high priestess).
The culture of Castovia is highly influenced by things from our universe - Roman Catholicism, its iconography, Holy Week in Spain and Spanish culture. The architecture of Castovia is magnificent, often designed to glorify their gods. Sometimes burning days are held in the towns of Castovia. These days, everyone who is forbidden to be in the territory of Castovia is burned alive.

3.content:
Grimhaven is the exact opposite of Castovia. Grimhaven welcomes all sentient beings into its territory, and all forms of magic are allowed except for dark and holy magic. Religion is not prohibited, but since Grimhaven and Castovia are in a state of constant war, mentioning religion may cause some locals to look at you with suspension. Due to the diverse population and magic, maintaining order in the towns can be challenging, and corruption is present, although not as severe as in Orthar. 
Grimhaven's culture is quite vague, but its architectural style is clearly inspired by Gothic styles.

4.content: Orthar, a region for those who have no place else to go. The level of lawlessness and banditry here is the highest among all three regions. The law enforcement agencies are more of a threat than a protection. At some point, it is safer to live outside the towns, as many people do, forming their own small communities and villages. Yes, you won't be killed for not believing in God or having horns, because to kill someone in Orthar you don't need any reason. Although, death is better than sex slavery. Right?

5.content: Black Demons are one of the races that live in this world. They have nothing to do with real demons, and their name comes from their distinctive horns and black skin. Black Demons are stronger than average humans and have a natural affinity for dark magic, but they are also very voracious and can be easily caught off guard when they are hungry. There are not many Black Demons left in the world, which makes them valuable to slave traders and bounty hunters.
